<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acknowledgements">ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acknowledgements" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A text book on a ny subject cannot be written without the help and assistance of a number of people. They include peers, contemporaries, colleagues, students, technical and non-technical assistants, etc. Therefore, it has to be acknowledged that I owe much to many people, who I will not able to thank individually. Yet, I feel that I need to put on record my sincere gratitude to the following people for their guidance, help and assistance.</p>
<p>The seed for the preparation of this textbook was sown in my mind by one of my students, Mr. Sridhar, who suggested that I should compile all my earlier lectures and notes into a book for the benefit of undergraduate students, who find it difficult to comprehend the complexities of other books on the subject. I am thankful to him for his suggestion.</p>
<p>I am deeply indebted to Dr. B. M. Rudresh, Professor &amp; Head, Department of Biochemistry, AIMedical College, Mandya, India for his guidance and encouragement. I am grateful to Dr. Naseem Begum and Dr. Mohammed Muzaffar Shakeel for their valuable suggestions. I am thankful to all my colleagues, friends and relatives for their moral support.</p>
<p>I acknowledge that the material contained in this book is sourced from the standard literature available. I have tried to compile as much of the subject as necessary, and as little as possible, so as to fulfill the needs of undergraduate students of Medicine and Allied Sciences.</p>
<p>This book would not have been completed, but for the constant support and assistance of my wife Razia Rashida Parveen, who has been with me, through thick and thin, at every step and every stage of our married life. She has been deeply involved in the preparation of the manuscript and illustrations of this book. I am thankful to her for everything.</p>
<p>I am thankful to my parents for providing me with the best of education and upbringing. Their love and affection have been a constant source of strength throughout my life.</p>
<p>Finally, I supplicate myself to Almighty God for His Grace and Mercy. All Praise is due, to Him Alone.</p>
<p>Dr. Mohammed Amanullah
14th March 2012</p>

<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1">1<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-80b1c19f.jpeg" alt="img-4.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="biochemistry">BIOCHEMISTRY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biochemistry" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="scope-and-importance-in-medical-sciences">SCOPE AND IMPORTANCE IN MEDICAL SCIENCES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#scope-and-importance-in-medical-sciences" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Biochemistry is the answer to an innocent mind questioning itself as to—What is life? What is growth? What is maturity? What is a disease? And finally, what is death? In short, answers to two of these most important questions can be cited here.</p>
<p><strong>What is life?</strong></p>
<p>Life is an organized state of a few elements.</p>
<p><strong>What is Death?</strong></p>
<p>Death is a state of disorganization of these elements.</p>
<p>It is said that man is made out of mud and there are about 93 elements in the mud or the earth's crust. Among these many elements, only a few of them arrange in a specific order to give rise to life. Any disorder in these elements results in a disease which may lead to death. Therefore, Biochemistry is the study of elements which make life and the fashion in which they are arranged. It also explains the functioning of these elements which trigger and continue the process of life. The extent of de-arrangement of the life making elements, may either lead to disease or cause death.</p>
<p>Medical professionals undertake Biochemistry in order to deal specifically with different methodologies of prevention and rectification of various disorders thus bringing back the body to function normally thereby helping in leading a healthy life and delaying the process of death.</p>
<p>Human body is made up of myriad of molecules (union of elements). What are these molecules? What are their properties and characteristics? How are they aligned with each other to make possible the living state? In this book we will study the molecules forming the living matter and correlation of biological function with the molecular structure. From its study, Biochemistry has come to the conclusion that, matter in an appropriate physico-chemical state of organization acquires the traits of living substances.</p>
<p>Let us now list out exactly those elements that form life. The elements that give rise to life can be grouped into two categories—</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Major elements:</strong> The elements which are found in large quantities in the human body are major elements. They include—carbon (C), hydrogen (H), oxygen (O), nitrogen (N), phosphorus (P), sulphur (S) and calcium (Ca).</li>
</ol>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Minor elements: The elements which are found in lesser quantities in the human body are minor-elements. They are further classified into two groups—</li>
</ol>
<p>(a) Macro-elements: They include the elements that are present in relatively appreciable amounts in the body, viz., iron (Fe), sodium (Na) and potassium (K).</p>
<p>(b) Micro-elements: They include the elements that are present in minute quantities in the body, viz., cobalt (Co), copper (Cu), magnesium (Mg), manganese (Mn), arsenic (Ar), lead (Pb) and iodine (I).</p>
<p>These elements combine in different ratios and proportions to make a molecule. For instance C, H, and O combine in 1:2:1 ratio to make carbohydrates. Similarly, C, H, O and N combine to form proteins and lipids. Nucleic acids are the result of combination of C, H, O, N and P. Carbohydrates, proteins, lipids and nucleic acids, grouped under a category called macromolecules, form the basic components that make life possible. In addition to these molecules there are micromolecules like hormones, vitamins and minerals that also play a vital role in the process of life. Among the macromolecules, proteins and nucleic acids are known as informational macromolecules and the other two, viz., carbohydrates, lipids are non-informational macromolecules. The areas of study of Biochemistry are the study of structure of these molecules, their properties, their functions, their inter-relationship and their metabolism. In order to study these characters it becomes necessary to isolate them, separate them, purify them and bring them into a suitable form so that it can easily be analyzed and characterized. Hence, Biochemistry also deals with methods and techniques to isolate, purify and characterize various compounds.</p>
<p>Biochemistry deals not only at the molecular level but also at the level of the cell. A cell can suitably be defined as the theatre of life, where each and every artist (molecules) play their role (functions) exactly as the director (DNA) wants, and the director directs exactly as that appreciated and enjoyed by the audience (cell organelles). Biochemistry has proved that the above cooperation exists well for normal functioning of a cell and thereby of a living organism. A little misunderstanding between them leads to disturbances in the cell and finally may lead to death of the living organism.</p>
<p>The main purpose of all the efforts of Biochemistry is to benefit humans in all forms, particularly in diagnosis and treatment of various diseases. For example, measurement of serum levels of isoenzymes helps in the diagnosis and degree of various tissue disorders. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) has five isoenzyme forms, of which <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{LDH}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">LDH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{LDH}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">LDH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> levels in the serum increase following a myocardial infarction (heart attack). Due to the knowledge of enzyme inhibition, it has become possible to treat various diseases. Some bacteria do not require preformed folic acid (a vitamin for humans) as growth factor because they can make it if P-aminobenzoic acid (PABA), one of the components of folic acid, is available. Thus PABA is a vitamin for these bacteria. If sulphanilamide is administered, it competes with PABA in the enzymatic synthesis of folic acid due to its structural similarity and inhibits the growth of pathogenic bacteria requiring PABA. Likewise, allopurinol, a drug, is used to treat Gout, a disease of the joints, where there is an abnormal accumulation of uric acid crystals. Allopurinol competitively inhibits xanthine oxidase, the enzyme responsible for converting purines into uric acid.</p>
<p>Investigations of diabetes mellitus are completely based upon the laboratory tests in Biochemistry labs, where the presence of sugar in urine is tested by Benedict's test. Similarly, investigation of other disorders like albuminuria, lactosuria, etc. are carried out here.</p>
<p>Due to the recent knowledge of cell receptors for various substances it has become possible to treat hormonal disorders and to kill cancerous cells without affecting other cells. Toxic substances are encapsulated in membranous cells having complimentary surface receptors to that of cancerous cells. These capsulated cells when injected gets attached to the cancerous cells due to their complimentarity and release the toxic substances into the cancerous cells destroying them.</p>
<p>The technique of enzyme immobilization has helped in the treatment of various in born errors of metabolism. The most recent advancement in the technique of "gene manipulation" has helped in the large scale, artificial synthesis of peptide hormones like insulin and synthesis of enzymes making the use of micro-organism. Hence it can be concluded that Biochemistry is the tool to make diagnosis of certain diseases.</p>
<p>The scope of Biochemistry is as vast as the sky. It is not limited to a particular aspect. There is no end to Biochemistry research, it is growing and growing thousand times, as fast as a malignant tumour.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-e57db069.jpeg" alt="img-5.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-13f98bd1.jpeg" alt="img-6.jpeg"></p>
<p>If we look at our body we can see that it is made up of flesh and bones. But definitely, a question comes to our mind as to what is this flesh and bones made up of? The answer to this question is given by biochemistry. In anatomy you study, as to how the different organs of our body are arranged and in physiology you study the functions of these organs, but biochemistry shows what they are made up of and how do they function.</p>
<p>Human body can be divided into a number of divisions or parts, the least particle being the electron, which cannot be divided further. The electron is negatively charged particle. Similarly, there is a positively charged particle called proton and neutral particle known as neutron which also cannot be divided further. The electron, proton and neutron collectively form the atom (if named in particular is called as an element).</p>
<p>A second question arises in our mind as to how and wherefrom did these particles come into living beings. The answer to this question from the developing science is that before the formation of the earth, a bunch of fire got separated from the sun containing, solemnly these particles, viz., electrons, protons and neutrons. On gradual cooling of this fire the electrons, protons and neutrons combined in different numbers to give rise to a substance called atom or element. Up till now 93 different kinds of elements are found in earth's crust. The periodic table of elements is given below—</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>1H 1 HYDROGEN</th><th>Atomic← Number</th><th>6C 12→ Atomic Weight</th><th>Major element</th><th></th><th>2He 4 HELIUM</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>3Li 7 LITHIUM</td><td>4Be 9 BERYLLUM</td><td>CARBON</td><td>Macro-element</td><td>5B 11 BONIN</td><td>6C 12 CARBON</td><td>7N 14 NITROGEN</td></tr><tr><td>11Na 23 SODIUM</td><td>12Mg 24 MAONESIUM</td><td>Micro-element</td><td>13Al 27 ALMONIUM</td><td>14Si 28 SILICON</td><td>15P 31 PHOSPHORUS</td><td>16S 32 SULPHUR</td></tr><tr><td>19K 39 POTASSIUM</td><td>20Ca 40 CALCIUM</td><td>21Sc 45 SCANDIUM</td><td>22Ti 48 TITANIUM</td><td>23V 51 VANADIUM</td><td>24Cr 52 CHROMIUM</td><td>25Mn 55 MANGANASIS</td></tr><tr><td>37Rb 85 PURIDIUM</td><td>38Sr 88 STROXYIUM</td><td>39Y 89 VITRIUM</td><td>40Zr 91 ZRICINIUM</td><td>41Nb 93 NICOSIUM</td><td>42Mo 96 NOLYSODIUM</td><td>43Tc 98 TECHNTIUM</td></tr><tr><td>55Cs 133 CEDIUM</td><td>56Ba 137 BARIUM</td><td></td><td>72Hf 178 VAXINUM</td><td>73Ta 181 THATSULIN</td><td>74W 184 THATSULIN</td><td>75Re 186 THADIUM</td></tr><tr><td>87Fr 223 FRANCUM</td><td>88Ra 226 RAZUM</td><td></td><td>Lanthanides</td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><strong>Structure of an atom:</strong> Where there are many numbers of electrons, protons and neutrons, there are a number of possibilities of their being combined with each other. Let us start with number one. Supposing there is one electron, you know it is negatively charged, so it will combine with a positively charged proton to form an atom. To recognize this atom it is given a particular name. The atom or the element with one electron and one proton is known as hydrogen. Likewise an atom with a combination of two electrons, two protons and two neutrons is known as helium atom. Lithium has three numbers of each, etc. etc.</p>
<p><strong>Atomic number:</strong> The atomic number of an atom is the number of electrons in that atom (or net positive charge on that atom).</p>
<p><strong>Atomic weight:</strong> It is the mass of an atom. The elements most commonly found in our body are - hydrogen, oxygen, carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulphur, etc.</p>
<p>The final question is: <em>Why and how do these elements form the different organs of our body?</em> So the answer is: All the atoms except <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^2\mathrm{He}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">He</span></span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>10</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{10}\mathrm{Ne}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Ne</span></span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>18</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{18}\mathrm{Ar}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">18</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Ar</span></span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>36</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{36}\mathrm{Kr}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">36</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Kr</span></span></span></span></span></span>, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>54</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{54}\mathrm{Xe}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">54</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Xe</span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mn>86</mn></msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">^{86}\mathrm{Rh}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">86</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Rh</span></span></span></span></span></span> (inert elements/noble gases) are unstable, hence in order to attain stability they combine with each other and thereby also attain the noble gas configuration. In order to attain stability they either gain, loose or share electrons from, to or with other atoms respectively.</p>
<ol>
<li><strong>Sharing of electrons:</strong> Hydrogen having one electron shares an electron with another hydrogen so that both of them can now have two electrons each which is a stable configuration as that of helium.</li>
</ol>
<p>The aggregation of two or more atoms is known as a molecule. In the hydrogen molecule, a force of attraction develops due to sharing of electrons, which holds the two hydrogen atoms together. This force is known as a chemical bond. A bond formed by mutual sharing of electrons is known as a covalent bond.</p>
<p>(a) <strong>Single bond:</strong> If one electron from each of the sharing atoms are contributed for the bond formation, then a single bond results (C–C).</p>
<p>(b) <strong>Double bond:</strong> If two electrons from each of the sharing atoms are contributed for bond formation, then a double bond is formed (C = C).</p>
<p>(c) <strong>Triple bond:</strong> If three electrons are shared (C≡C).</p>
<ol start="2">
<li><strong>Unequal sharing of electrons or coordinate bond:</strong> Here both the electrons for sharing between the two atoms are contributed by one atom only. For example in the formation of ammonium ion (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo></msubsup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NH}_4^+</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0916em; vertical-align: -0.247em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -2.453em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">+</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) from ammonia and proton (hydrogen ion) two electrons are contributed by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NH}_3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ol>
<p>There is a second type of coordinate bond wherein the sharing electrons are pulled more towards one of the atoms. For example, in water molecule <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo>−</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>−</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}-\mathrm{O}-\mathrm{H}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">H</span></span></span></span></span>, the electrons are more towards oxygen atom than towards hydrogen atom. Hence the bond formed due to unequal sharing of electrons is known as co-ordinate or native or semi-polar bond.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li><strong>Transfer of electron (gain or loss of electrons):</strong> Sodium (Na) contains an electron more than its neighbour inert gas (neon), and chlorine (Cl) contains an electron less than its neighbour inert gas (Argon). Hence the Na atom donates an electron to Cl to form NaCl (sodium chloride). A bond formed by the complete transfer of one or more electrons of an atom to another atom is known as ionic bond.</li>
</ol>
<p><strong>The following are a few important molecules found in biological systems—</strong></p>
<ul>
<li>The combination of carbon and hydrogen is known as “hydrocarbon” (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\mathrm{CH}-</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CH</span></span><span class="mord">−</span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
<li>The group of carbon compounds containing an <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\mathrm{OH}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span></span></span></span></span> are called as “alcohols” (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\mathrm{CHOH}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CHOH</span></span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
<li>The group of compounds containing ‘C’ double bond ‘O’ with one hydrogen and one carbon are called “aldehydes” (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\mathrm{CHO}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CHO</span></span></span></span></span></span>). (C = O with 2H also).</li>
<li>The group of compounds containing ‘C’ double bond ‘O’ with two ‘C’ substitutes are called “ketones” (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mo>−</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mo>−</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{C}-\mathrm{CO}-\mathrm{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">C</span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
<li>Compounds containing carboxylic group are called “carboxylic acids” (<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\mathrm{COOH}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">COOH</span></span></span></span></span></span>).</li>
</ul>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>These molecules along with a few other elements combine to give rise to carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, nucleic acids etc. which in turn contributes to the structure and life of an organism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="water">WATER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#water" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5017f6b5.jpeg" alt="img-7.jpeg"></p>
<p>Water is the major component of our body. It constitutes about 70% of the total body mass. Most of the reactions in the cell are carried out in aqueous medium (water).</p>
<p>Water is made up of oxygen and two hydrogen atoms. Oxygen has a tendency to pull the electrons more towards itself, thereby becoming electronegative and leaving the hydrogens electropositive. This results in the creation of a dipole due to which each water molecule is surrounded by four other water molecules.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-b16d3979.jpeg" alt="img-8.jpeg"></p>
<p>The bond between 'H' of one water molecule and 'O' of the other is known as hydrogen bond.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="properties">Properties:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#properties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>It has a high boiling point when compared to other liquids.</li>
<li>It has a high specific heat of vaporization.</li>
<li>High melting point.</li>
<li>The pH of water is 7.</li>
</ol>
<p>Specific heat of water is one calorie, it is, therefore, best suited to maintain constant temperature of the body with varying environmental temperature.</p>
<p>The heat of vaporization of 540 cal/gram at 100 °C is helpful in maintaining the body temperature, i.e., large amount of body heat is lost with only a small amount of water being vaporized from the surface of the skin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acids-and-bases">ACIDS AND BASES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acids-and-bases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>An acid is a proton- donor and a base is a proton- acceptor (Bronsted-Lowry theory).</p>
<p>Acids:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{HCl} \rightarrow \mathrm{H}^{+} + \mathrm{Cl}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HCl</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9047em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8213em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8557em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Cl</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>3</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CH_3COOH} \rightarrow \mathrm{CH_3COO}^{-} + \mathrm{H}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">COOH</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9946em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">COO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8213em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8213em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>Weak acids are those which have a slight tendency to give up protons. e.g., acetic acid. On the other hand, strong acids give up protons readily. e.g., HCl.</p>
<p>Bases:</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NaOH} \rightarrow \mathrm{Na}^{+} + \mathrm{OH}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NaOH</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9279em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Na</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mo>→</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H_2O} \rightarrow \mathrm{H}^{+} + \mathrm{OH}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9047em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8213em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>There are strong and weak bases similar to that of acids. e.g., NaOH is a strong base which releases hydroxyl ions very easily, and water is a weak base as it is a poor source of hydroxyl ions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ph">pH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>pH is defined as the negative logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration in a media.</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>10</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></msub><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo fence="true">]</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{pH} = -\mathrm{Log}_{(10)} \left[ \mathrm{H}^{+} \right]</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">pH</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2691em; vertical-align: -0.4191em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Log</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2809em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mopen mtight">(</span><span class="mord mtight">10</span><span class="mclose mtight">)</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.4191em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">[</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8213em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">]</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>In simple terms it is a value that gives the amount of hydrogen ions present in a solution. This value is expressed in a reverse or negative form, i.e., higher the pH value lower is the hydrogen ion concentration and lower the pH value higher is the hydrogen ion concentration. The pH of all the solutions ranges between 0 and 14 only. pH of value 7.0 is neutral and pH ranging from 0 to 6.9 is acidic and 7.1 to 14 is basic or alkaline. The water molecule dissociates as—</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O} \rightarrow \mathrm{H}^{+} + \mathrm{OH}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9047em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8213em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">OH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>The hydrogen ion concentration in pure water was found to be 0.0000001 moles/litre.</p>
<p>This can also be written as <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>10000000</mn></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\frac{1}{10000000}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1901em; vertical-align: -0.345em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8451em;"><span style="top: -2.655em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">10000000</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.394em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.345em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span> or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \times 10^{-7}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">×</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span><span class="mord mtight">7</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>Taking log of the above number we get = -7.</p>
<p>Negative logarithm of the above number = 7.</p>
<p>The negative logarithm of the hydrogen ion concentration is known as pH. Therefore, the pH of water is 7. To calculate the pH of any weak dissociable acid, the following equation is derived—</p>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mo>⇔</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{HA} \Leftrightarrow \mathrm{H}^{+} + \mathrm{A}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HA</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">⇔</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9047em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8213em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8213em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">A</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8213em;"><span style="top: -3.113em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo fence="true">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup><mo fence="true">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mo fence="true">]</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{K}_{a} = \frac{ \left[ \mathrm{H}^{+} \right] \left[ \mathrm{A}^{-} \right] }{ \left[ \mathrm{HA} \right] }</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">a</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.3843em; vertical-align: -0.936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.4483em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HA</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">]</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">]</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">A</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">]</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.936em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo fence="true">]</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>−</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mo fence="true">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup><mo fence="true">]</mo></mrow></mfrac></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\log \left[ \mathrm{H}^{+} \right] = -\log \mathrm{K}_{a} - \mathrm{Log} \frac{ \left[ \mathrm{HA} \right] }{ \left[ \mathrm{A}^{-} \right] }</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">]</span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; vertical-align: -0.936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Log</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.427em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">A</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6973em;"><span style="top: -2.989em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">]</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HA</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">]</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.936em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span></span></span></span></span></div>
<div class="math math-display"><span class="katex-display"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" display="block"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mi>a</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mi>log</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup><mo fence="true">]</mo></mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">[</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mo fence="true">]</mo></mrow></mfrac><mi mathvariant="normal">.</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{pH} = \mathrm{pK}_{a} + \log \frac{ \left[ \mathrm{A}^{-} \right] }{ \left[ \mathrm{HA} \right] }.</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">pH</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9275em; vertical-align: -0.2441em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">pK</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.0573em;"><span style="top: -2.4559em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">a</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.2441em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">+</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 2.3843em; vertical-align: -0.936em;"></span><span class="mop">lo<span style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mfrac"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.4483em;"><span style="top: -2.314em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HA</span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">]</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.23em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="frac-line" style="border-bottom-width: 0.04em;"></span></span><span style="top: -3.677em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 3em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">A</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">]</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.936em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose nulldelimiter"></span></span><span class="mord">.</span></span></span></span></span></div>
<p>This is known as the "Henderson-Hasselbalch equation".</p>
<p>The normal pH of blood plasma ranges between 7.35 and 7.45, average being 7.4. The intracellular pH of the tissues is 7.25 to 7.35 averaging to 7.30 and pH of extracellular fluid is 7.30 to 7.40 with an average of 7.35. A decrease in the pH of blood is termed as acidosis and an increase in the pH of blood is termed as alkalosis. Alkalosis is more fatal than acidosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="buffers">BUFFERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#buffers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A buffer solution is one which resists the changes in pH of a solution upon the addition of small amount of acid or alkali. Buffer solutions are a mixture of—</p>
<p>(a) Weak acid and its salt (or its conjugate base).
(b) Weak base and its salt (or its conjugate acid).
(c) Weak acid and weak base. e.g., weak acid <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{COOH}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">COOH</span></span></span></span></span></span> and its base <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CH}_{3} \mathrm{COONa}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">COONa</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>There are two important chemical buffers that act in the biological system, they are—</p>
<ol>
<li>Bicarbonate buffer: Contains a mixture of carbonic acid <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{H}_2\mathrm{CO}_3)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em;
