<li>Lactose: Made up of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -D-galactopyrasone and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -D-glucopyranose linked through  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -1→4 glycosidic linkage. Chemically it is called as  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -D-galactopyranosyl- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -1→4)- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -D-glucopyranose. It is present in milk and hence called milk sugar. It is a reducing sugar and forms puff shaped osazone crystals.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-1aa0db16.jpeg" alt="img-42.jpeg"></p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Sucrose: Contains  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -D-glycopyranse and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -D-fructofuranose linked through  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -1→2 glycosidic linkage. Its chemical name is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -D-glucopyranosyl-( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -1→2)- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -D-fructofuranose. It is the common table sugar obtained from sugar cane hence the name cane sugar. As it is a non-reducing sugar it does not form osazones. It is also known as invert sugar.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-90c753b8.jpeg" alt="img-43.jpeg"></p>
<p>Invert sugar: Sucrose is known as invert sugar because sucrose is dextrorotatory with a specific rotation of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>62.5</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">+62.5^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7574em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">+</span><span class="mord">62.</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> . On hydrolysis by an enzyme - sucrase or invertase, it gives a mixture of glucose and fructose. This mixture exhibits a net specific rotation of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>19</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">∘</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-19^{\circ}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7574em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">9</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6741em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">∘</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> , i.e., levorotatory. The phenomenon by which dextrorotatory sugar is converted to a levorotatory sugar is known as invert sugar.</p>
<p>Chocolate companies use invertase enzyme in the preparation of toffees in order to increase the taste and commercial value. In the preparation of these toffees solid sucrose caramel is made and coated with the enzyme-sucrase or invertase over which cocoa is engorged. The enzyme hydrolyses solid sucrose into liquid glucose and fructose which is seventy times sweeter, thereby attracting the consumer.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="polysaccharides">POLYSACCHARIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#polysaccharides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Carbohydrates made up of 10 or more monosaccharide units are called as polysaccharides. They are also known as glycans. They are further classified as homopolysaccharides and heteropolysaccharides.</p>
<p>Homopolysaccharides: Those polysaccharides which contain only one kind of monosaccharide unit are called homopolysaccharides. e.g., starch, glycogen, cellulose, dextran, inulin, agar, chitin, etc.</p>
<ol>
<li>Glycogen: It is known as animal starch. It is made up of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -D-glucose units linked by  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -1→4 linkages in the linear and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -1→6 linkages at the branching points. It is highly branched. Glycogen is the storage form of energy (glucose) in each and every cell of the human body. Liver and muscle contain the highest amount of glycogen. At least  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span>  of glycogen is present in each cell even under severe fasting/starvation condition. It gives a red colour with iodine.</li>
<li>Starch: It is made up of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -D-glucose units, hence known as glucosan. It is composed of amylose and amylopectin. Amylose is coiled and unbranched. The  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -D-glucose units are linked by glycosidic linkages. Amylopectin is uncoiled and is highly branched. It has  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -1→4 linkages in the linear chain and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -1→6 at the branching points. It is the chief carbohydrates present in plants and forms the main source of dietary energy sources to humans. It gives a blue colour with iodine.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ce61302e.jpeg" alt="img-44.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ad8061b2.jpeg" alt="img-45.jpeg"></p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Cellulose: Made up of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -D-glucose units linked by  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -1→4 glycosidic linkages. It is unbranched. It is the most abundant carbohydrate in nature. It forms the woods of the plant. Cellulase enzyme is absent in human being and hence it becomes non-utilizable. However, it adds to the bulk of the food and helps in the gastric motility.</li>
<li>Dextran: It is produced by yeasts and bacteria. It is made up of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -D-glucose linked by  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -1→6 glycosidic linkages. The branching points are at 1-2, 1-3 and 1-4. It absorbs water to form gels. It is used as plasma substitute.</li>
<li>Inulin: It is a fructosan. It cannot be metabolized by the body, hence used to assay glomerular filtration rate (G.F.R.) in the study of kidney function.</li>
<li>Agar: It is a sulphated galactose. It dissolves in hot water. It gels on cooling, thereby forming a solidified medium in tissue culture studies.</li>
<li>Chitin:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> -acetylglucosamine (chitosamine) linked by  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>→</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta - 1 \rightarrow 4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span></span>  linkages. Present in the exoskeleton of invertebrates like cockroach and crab.</li>
</ol>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>Heteropolysaccharides: Polysaccharides made up of two or more kinds of monosaccharide units. e.g., pectins and mucopolysaccharides.</p>
<p>Most of them are branched and exist in conjugation with proteins and hence called proteoglycans. The carbohydrate part is called glycosaminoglycan. They have a repeating disaccharide unit which is acetylated or sulphated. There are two major types of heteropolysaccharides.</p>
<p>(a) Pectins: They are composed of galacturonic acid, galactose and arabinose.
(b) Mucopolysaccharides: They are sticky polysaccharides (mucin like). The various types of mucopolysaccharides and their composition is given below—</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Mucopolysaccharide</th><th>Composition</th><th>Importance</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Hyaluronic acid</td><td>1. D-Glucuronic acid</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>N-Acetyl-D-glucosamine | Occurs in synovial fluid, skin and vitreous humour.  |
|  2. Chondroitin sulphate | 1. D-Glucouronic acid</li>
<li>N-Acetyl-D-galactosamine sulphate | Component of cartilage, tendons and skin (connective tissue).  |
|  3. Dermatan sulphate | 1. L-Ioduronic acid</li>
<li>N-Acetyl-D-galactosamine sulphate | Present in skin.  |
|  4. Keratan sulphate | 1. D-galactose</li>
<li>N-Acetyl-D-glucosamine sulphate | Component of cartilage and cornea.  |
|  5. Heparin | 1. D- Ioduronic acid (sulphated)</li>
<li>N-Acetyl-D-glucosamine (sulphated) | Present in most cells especially in liver, lungs and arterial walls.  |</li>
</ol>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="5">5<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#5" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter">CHAPTER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-79b87967.jpeg" alt="img-46.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lipids">LIPIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lipids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Lipids are heterogenous group of compounds related either directly or indirectly (potentially) to fatty acids. They are insoluble in water but soluble in fat solvents like ether and benzene.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fatty-acids">FATTY ACIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fatty-acids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>They are the monocarboxylic acids with a long hydrocarbon chain. The minimum number of carbon atoms required to be called as fatty acid is 4.</p>
<p>H₃C CH₃ CH₂ CH₂ CH₂ CH₂ CH₂ CH₂ CH₂ CH₂ COOH</p>
<p>Fatty acid</p>
<p>There are two types of fatty acids (1) Saturated fatty acids, (2) Unsaturated fatty acids.</p>
<ol>
<li>Saturated fatty acids: These fatty acids contain only single bonds along the length of the carbon chain, i.e., all the carbon atoms are fully saturated with hydrogen atoms.</li>
</ol>
<p>The fatty acids found in the human body contain odd number (4, 6, 8, ...) of carbon atoms. All these are solids at room temperature. The various saturated fatty acids and the numbers of carbon atoms are:</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Name of the fatty acid</th><th></th><th>Carbon Nos.</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1.</td><td>Butyric acid</td><td>4</td></tr><tr><td>2.</td><td>Lauric acid</td><td>12</td></tr><tr><td>3.</td><td>Myristic acid</td><td>14</td></tr><tr><td>Name of the fatty acid</td><td></td><td>Carbon Nos.</td></tr><tr><td>---</td><td>---</td><td>---</td></tr><tr><td>4.</td><td>Palmitic acid</td><td>16</td></tr><tr><td>5.</td><td>Stearic acid</td><td>18</td></tr><tr><td>6.</td><td>Arachidic acid</td><td>20</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Unsaturated fatty acids: These fatty acids contain one or more double bonds along the length of the hydrocarbon chain.</li>
</ol>
<p>In human tissues, the double bond is of -cis type (i.e., the substituents are on the same side of the double bond). To represent the position of the double bond in a fatty acid, it is represented as Delta  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span></span></span></span></span>  ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>n</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\Delta^n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">Δ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.6644em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ), where  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span></span></span></span></span>  shows the position of double bond between the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">n</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">n</span></span></span></span></span> th carbon atom and the carbon atom next to it towards the omega (last) carbon atom. Unsaturated fatty acids are all liquids at room temperature. They are further classified depending upon the number of double bonds present per fatty acid as—</p>
<p>(a) Monounsaturated fatty acids: They contain only one double bond per fatty acid.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Name of the fatty acid</th><th></th><th>Number of carbon atoms</th><th>Position of the double bond</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1.</td><td>Palmitoleic acid</td><td>16</td><td>cis Δ⁹</td></tr><tr><td>2.</td><td>Oleic acid</td><td>18</td><td>cis Δ⁹</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>(b) Polyunsaturated fatty acids: They contain two or more double bonds along the length of the hydrocarbon chains.</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Name of the fatty acid</th><th></th><th>No. of carbon atoms</th><th>No. of double bonds</th><th>Position of the double bond</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1.</td><td>Linoleic acid</td><td>18</td><td>2</td><td>cis Δ^{9, 12}</td></tr><tr><td>2.</td><td>Linolenic acid</td><td>18</td><td>3</td><td>cis Δ^{9, 12, 15}</td></tr><tr><td>3.</td><td>Arachidonic acid</td><td>20</td><td>4</td><td>cis Δ^{5, 8, 11, 14}</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The polyunsaturated fatty acids are also known as essential fatty acids as they cannot be synthesized in the body and hence must be taken through the diet.</p>
<p>The other classes of fatty acids are—</p>
<p>(a) Cyclic fatty acids: Chaulmorgic acid
(b) Hydroxy fatty acids: (i) Saturated—Cerebronic acid and (ii) Unsaturated—Ricinoleic acid.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ab14fb5e.jpeg" alt="img-47.jpeg">
Classification of lipids:</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="simple-lipids">SIMPLE LIPIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#simple-lipids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>They are esters of fatty acids with alcohol. Depending upon the alcohol, they are further classified as—</p>
<ol>
<li>Neutral fats: These are esters of fatty acids with glycerol (a trihydric alcohol). These are known as triacylglycerols (TAG) or triglycerides.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-e9f735d9.jpeg" alt="img-48.jpeg">
Triacylglycerol</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R_{1}, R_{2},</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0077em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0077em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>R</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R_{3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0077em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  are the three fatty acids. All the three may be the same or different. If all the three  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>R</mi><mi>s</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R_{s}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0077em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">s</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  are the same, then it may be, Tripalmitin-3 palmitic acids esterified with glycerol. Tristearin-3 stearic acids esterified with glycerol.</p>
<p>If the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.00773em;">R</span></span></span></span></span>  groups are different then it is spelled out as Palmeto-stearo-olein indicating that glycerol is esterified with palmitic acid, stearic acid and oleic acid.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Waxes: These are esters of long chain fatty acids with long chain alcohol. e.g., Bee wax is ester of oleic acid (18 carbons) and oleyl alcohol (18 carbons).</li>
</ol>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="compound-lipids">COMPOUND LIPIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#compound-lipids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Simple lipids in combination with some other group are called compound lipids. Depending upon the group attached (prosthetic group) the compound lipids are further classified as—</p>
<ol>
<li>Phospholipids: They contain a phosphoric acid as the prosthetic group. Depending upon the alcohol present they are further classified as—</li>
</ol>
<p>(a) Glycerophospholipids: They contain the alcohol-glycerol. The components of glycerophospholipids are glycerol, two fatty acids (the one at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -position is saturated fatty acid and the other at  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -position is unsaturated), phosphoric acid and a base. Glycerol, fatty acids and phosphate together form a phosphatide to which a base is attached. Depending upon the base present there are various glycerophospholipids.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Phophatidyl choline or lecithin: Here the base is choline</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-fa097e02.jpeg" alt="img-49.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ba06b0f0.jpeg" alt="img-50.jpeg"></p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Phosphatidyl ethanolamine or cephalin: Here the base is ethanol amine, attached through - OH group.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0ed455c0.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg"></p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Phosphatidyl serine: Here the base is the amino acid serine.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-4afdbea6.jpeg" alt="img-52.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-bfd51380.jpeg" alt="img-53.jpeg"></p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  Phosphatidyl inositol: Here the base is inositol.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-cf102d39.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f41bae9b.jpeg" alt="img-55.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⇒</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\Rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">⇒</span></span></span></span></span>  Plasminogen: Here one of the fatty acids of the phosphatide is replaced by a long chain aldehyde which is in an enolic form. The base may be choline or ethanolamine.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-a2e5a90e.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg"></p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>⇒</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\Rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">⇒</span></span></span></span></span>  Cardiolipin or diphosphatidyl glycerol: Here two phosphatide groups are linked together through a glycerol.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-9cd9f346.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg"></p>
<p>(b) Sphingophospholipids: These phospholipids have sphingol as the alcohol. Sphingol is an amino alcohol with a chain length of 18 carbons having a double bond at trans delta 4 position. An example of sphingophospholipid or sphingolipid is sphingomyelin, which contains a fatty acid at the amino group (and this combination, i.e., sphingol and fatty acid is known as ceramide), a phosphoric acid at the primary alcohol and the base choline is attached to this phosphate group.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-800f6eaa.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg"></p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Glycolipids: These lipids contain a carbohydrate attached to</li>
</ol>
<p>the sphingol at the primary alcohol. They are also known as glycosphingosides or cerebrosides.</p>
<p>(a) Glucocerebrosides: If the sugar is glucose, then they are called as glucocerebrosides.
(b) Galactocerebrosides: If the sugar is galactose then they are called as galactocerebrosides.
(c) Gangliosides: These are complex sphingolipids made up of several sugar units, viz., glucose, galactose, galactosamine and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> -acetyl-neuramic acid or sialic acid.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Lipoproteins: These are lipids in conjugation with proteins. They mainly function for the transport of lipids (hydrophobic) through the blood (hydrophilic). The different types of lipoproteins and their composition is—</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>Name of the lipoprotein</th><th>Composition</th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th>Function in the body</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>Protein</td><td></td><td>Triacyglycerol (TAG)</td><td>Phospholipid (PL)</td><td>Cholesterol</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Type</td><td>Percent</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Chylomicron</td><td>A,B,C,E</td><td>2</td><td>83</td><td>7</td><td>8</td><td>Transport digested lipids</td></tr><tr><td>Very low density lipoprotein (VLDL)</td><td>B,C,E</td><td>9</td><td>50</td><td>19</td><td>22</td><td>Transport TAG from liver to adipose tissue</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Contd. to next have.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>Contd. from previous page</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Name of the lipoprotein</th><th>Composition</th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th></th><th>Function in the body</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td></td><td>Protein</td><td></td><td>Triacyglycerol (TAG)</td><td>Phospholipid (PL)</td><td>Cholesterol</td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Type</td><td>Percent</td><td></td><td></td><td></td><td></td></tr><tr><td>Low density lipoprotein (LDL)</td><td>Apo B</td><td>21</td><td>10</td><td>22</td><td>47</td><td>Transport cholesterol from liver to kidney</td></tr><tr><td>High density lipoprotein (HDL)</td><td>A,C,D,E</td><td>33</td><td>8</td><td>29</td><td>30</td><td>Blood scavengers for cholesterol</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>These lipoproteins are classified depending upon their densities in water. The density of a lipoprotein depends upon the fat content of that lipoprotein, more the fat content lower the density and hence it floats on the surface of water (vice versa). The protein part in the lipoprotein is known as apoprotein. The various types of apoproteins found in lipoproteins are apoprotein- A, B, C, D, E. Lipoproteins also constitute the combination of membrane proteins with membrane lipids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="derived-lipids">DERIVED LIPIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#derived-lipids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>These are the compounds obtained on hydrolysis of simple and compound lipids. They also constitute all those compounds that are related to fatty acids. They include fatty acids, steroids, eicosanoids (prostanoids-prostaglandins, prostacyclins, thromboxanes-leukotrienes and lipoxins) carotenoids etc.</p>
<p>Steroids: All compounds containing the cyclo-pentano-perhydro-phenanthrene ring are called steroids. The most abundant steroids in the human body are the sterols, i.e., an alcohol (-OH) group is attached to the steroid nucleus. e.g., cholesterol, ergosterol, bile acids, sex hormones, adrenal cortical hormones and vitamin  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{D}_3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">D</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>Cholesterol is the major sterol in the body. It is a constituent of cell membrane and provides rigidity to it. Cholesterol acts as the precursor for all the other steroids in the body, viz., testosterone, estrogen, progesterone, vitamin-D, bile salts, corticosteroids, etc.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5ae4b125.jpeg" alt="img-59.jpeg">
Cyclo pentano perhydro phenanthrene</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-54325665.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg">
Cholesterol</p>
<p>Prostaglandins: They are the derivatives of polyunsaturated fatty acids, mainly the arachidonic acid  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>20</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{C}_{20})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">20</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>  or even linoleic acid  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mn>18</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{C}_{18})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">18</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> . They are 20 carbon fatty acids with a 5 membered ring.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-84b6eab2.jpeg" alt="img-61.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>There are four types of prostaglandins PGE, PGF, PGA and PGB. But only PGE and PGF are important. The E group of prostaglandins contains a keto group at C-9, two -OH groups at C-11 and C-15 positions. The various types of PGE are  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E}_3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-4d54ac0e.jpeg" alt="img-62.jpeg"></p>
<p>The PGF groups contain -OH group at all the three positions. The various types of PGF are  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{F}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{F}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{F}_3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">F</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> . Among the subtypes there are two more sub-subtypes in each of the prostaglandins, i.e.,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-387ee6a0.jpeg" alt="img-63.jpeg"></p>
<p>Functions of prostaglandins: Prostaglandins are synthesized in all tissues and cells except RBC. They act as local hormones and are destroyed immediately. Other functions include as under:</p>
<ol>
<li>They act as vasopressors and hence lower the blood pressure.</li>
<li>They are used in induction of labour, termination of pregnancy and prevention of conception.</li>
<li>They facilitate fertilization of the ovum.</li>
<li>They are used in the treatment of gastric ulcers, as they diminish HCl secretion.</li>
<li>They are used to prevent inflammation.</li>
<li>They are used in asthma and congenital heart diseases.</li>
<li>They promote platelet aggregation (after conversion to thromboxanes).</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PGE}_2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PGE</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  acts as a messenger between hormone receptor and adenylate cyclase enzyme.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemical-properties-of-lipids">Chemical properties of lipids:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-properties-of-lipids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Saponification: Hydrolysis of TAG with KOH or NaOH is called saponification or soap formation. These soaps are the household soaps. Sodium soaps are hard and potassium soaps are soft. Detergents have acidic group like sulphuric acid attached to the fatty acids.</li>
<li>Saponification number: It is the number of milligrams of KOH required to saponify the free and combined fat in 1 gram of a given fat. A high saponification number indicates that the fat is made up of low molecular weight fatty acids and vice versa.</li>
<li>Iodine number: It is the grams of iodine required to saturate 100 grams of fat. It is an indication of unsaturation.</li>
<li>Rancidity: Fats contaminated with enzymes like lipase undergo partial hydrolysis and oxidation of unsaturated fatty acids at the double bonds. This is even brought about by the atmospheric moisture and temperature. Due to this, there is release of hydrogen peroxide giving a bad odour and taste to the fat. This fat is said to be rancid and the process is known as rancidity. Rancidity can be prevented by antioxidants like vitamin E, vitamin C, phenols, hydroquinones, etc.</li>
</ol>
<p>Molecular structure of a cell membrane: Each cell and sub-cellular organelles are surrounded by a lipid bi-layer. 70 to 80 per cent are polar lipids and the remainder is mostly protein. The lipid part of</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>the membrane is polar or amphipathic lipid largely phosphoglycerides, some amounts of sphingolipids and a negligible amount of triacylglycerols. Cholesterol and cholesterol esters are also present in the membrane.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8306bd14.jpeg" alt="img-64.jpeg"></p>
<p>Membranes are very thin from 6 to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>9</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">9\mathrm{nm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">nm</span></span></span></span></span></span> , flexible and fluid. They are freely permeable to water but impermeable to electrically charged ions like  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">N</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">a</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mo>−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Cl^-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">l</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mbin mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and to polar but uncharged molecules like sugars. These impermeable substances are transported with the help of membrane transport proteins. On the other hand lipid soluble molecules readily pass through membranes.</p>
<p>Proteins are nitrogenous organic compounds of high molecular weight which play a vital or prime role in living organisms. They are made up of 20 standard α-amino acids. The main functions of proteins in human body are—</p>
<ol>
<li>They serve as body building units. e.g. muscle proteins.</li>
<li>They provide support and protection to various tissues. e.g. collagen and keratin.</li>
<li>All chemical reactions in the body are catalyzed by proteinaceous enzymes. e.g. trypsin.</li>
<li>They transport various molecules and ions from one organ to the other. e.g. hemoglobin, serum albumin.</li>
<li>They store and provide nutrients. e.g. milk casein, ovalbumin.</li>
<li>They defend the body from harmful foreign organisms. e.g. immunoglobulins, fibrinogen.</li>
<li>They help to regulate cellular or physiological activity. e.g. hormones, viz. insulin, GH.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="amino-acids">AMINO ACIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#amino-acids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Amino acids are the building blocks of proteins. Among the thousands of amino acids available in nature, proteins contain only 20 different kinds of amino acids, all of them are L-alpha-amino acids. The same 20 standard amino acids make proteins in all the living cells, may it either be a virus, bacteria, yeast, plant or human cell. These 20 amino acids combine in different sequences and numbers to form various kinds of proteins. The number of proteins that can be had from these 20 amino acids can be calculated from 20 factorial, i.e. 20 × 19 × 18 × 17 × 16 × .....× 2 × 1 = 2.4 × 10^{18}. In human beings alone there are more than 100 000 different types of proteins.</p>
<p>The general formulae for an amino acid can be written as ‘R-CH-NH_{2}--COOH'. Depending upon the ‘R' group present in the amino acid it is named accordingly. The 20 amino acids found in the proteins are known as primary or standard amino acids. In addition to these, some other amino acids are also found in proteins like 4-hydroxyproline, 5-hydroxylysine, 6-N-methyllysine, gamma carboxyglutamic acid and desmosine, all of these are derivatives of standard amino acids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="classification-of-amino-acids">CLASSIFICATION OF AMINO ACIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#classification-of-amino-acids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. Depending upon the charge: Amino acids can be broadly classified into three major groups (1) Neutral (2) Acidic and (3) Basic.</p>
<ol>
<li>Neutral amino acids: Those amino acids that do not contain any charge on the ‘R' group. They are further classified into the following categories—</li>
</ol>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>(a) Aliphatic: Those amino acids whose 'R' group contains a chain of carbon atoms-Gly, Ala, Ser, Thr, Val, Leu, Ile, Asn, Gln.
(b) Aromatic: Those amino acids whose 'R' group has a benzene ring-Phe, Tyr, Trp.
(c) Heterocyclic: The "R" group has a heterocyclic ring, i.e., any of the ring structures which contain different atoms-Pro, His.
(d) Sulphur containing: Those amino acids which contain a sulphur atom-Cys, Met.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Acidic amino acids: Those amino acids that contain a negative charge or an acidic group-Asp, Glu.</li>
<li>Basic amino acids: Those amino acids that contain a positive charge or a basic group-Arg, Lys and His.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-87ce0a71.jpeg" alt="img-65.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-70fcac95.jpeg" alt="img-66.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-9112cb31.jpeg" alt="img-67.jpeg">
Arginine (Arg)
Mw = 175.25</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f6f561ea.jpeg" alt="img-68.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-35054779.jpeg" alt="img-69.jpeg"></p>
<p>II. Depending upon the solubility in water: The amino acids can also be grouped into two different categories, depending upon their solubility in water. They are—</p>
<ol>
<li>Hydrophobic amino acids: Amino acids insoluble in water are known as hydrophobic amino acids. They are—Ala, Val, Leu, Ile, Pro, Met, Phe, Trp.</li>
<li>Hydrophilic amino acids: Amino acids soluble in water are known as hydrophilic amino acids. They are—Gly, Ser, Thr, Cys, Tyr, Asp, Asn, Glu, Gln, Lys, Arg, His.</li>
</ol>
<p>III. Depending upon their nutritional requirements: The amino acids are classified into two groups. They are—</p>
<ol>
<li>Essential amino acids: Are those which cannot be synthesized by the human body and hence they should be taken through the diet. There are 10 essential amino acids. Among these amino acids, arginine and histidine are known as semi-essential amino acids.</li>
</ol>
<table><thead><tr><th>M - Methionine</th><th>V - Valine</th><th>P - Phenylalanine</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>A - Arginine</td><td>I - Isoleucine</td><td>H - Histidine</td></tr><tr><td>T - Threonine</td><td>L - Leucine</td><td>Ly - Lysine</td></tr><tr><td>T - Tryptophan</td><td></td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Non-essential amino acids: These acids are those that can be synthesized in the human body and are not required in the diet. These include gly, ala, ser, pro, tyr, cys, asp, asn, glu, gln.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reactions-of-amino-acids">REACTIONS OF AMINO ACIDS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reactions-of-amino-acids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physical-characters-of-amino-acids">Physical characters of amino acids<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physical-characters-of-amino-acids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Zwitter ions: Amino acids have an acidic group (-COOH group), i.e., a proton, donor. They also have a basic group (-NH₂ group), i.e., a proton, acceptor. A compound capable of both donating and accepting protons and thus able to act either as an acid or a base is known as amphoteric molecule. Amino acids have both anions and cations in solution and such compounds are called zwitter ions.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0d48117f.jpeg" alt="img-70.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Isoelectric pH  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{pH}^{\mathrm{I}})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.1646em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">pH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9146em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">I</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> : The pH at which the positive charge on the amino acid (or any other molecule) is equal to the negative charges, is known as isoelectric pH. At this pH the net charge will be zero and hence it does not move either to positive (anode) or to negative (cathode) electrode, when subjected to an electric field. At  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{pH}^{\mathrm{I}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.109em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">pH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.9146em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">I</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  all the molecules exist in zwitter ion form.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0aa2e688.jpeg" alt="img-71.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chemical-properties">Chemical properties<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chemical-properties" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="1-reactions-due-to-amino-group">1. Reactions due to amino group<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#1-reactions-due-to-amino-group" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>(a) Ninhydrin test: This test identifies or detects amino acids. If amino acids are heated with ninhydrin, they form a purple blue coloured compound, which is measured colorimetrically.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-473d14d2.jpeg" alt="img-72.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-db66fe19.jpeg" alt="img-73.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>(b) Reaction with nitrous acid: It is a method by which amino acids are measured depending upon the amount of nitrogen released.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5444bb03.jpeg" alt="img-74.jpeg"></p>
<p>(c) Reaction with carbonyl compounds (RCHO): The amino group in the amino acids reacts with carbonyl compounds forming a Schiff's base.</p>
