margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  is predominantly present in the cardiac muscle, whereas the isoenzyme form  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>5</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{LDH}_5</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">LDH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">5</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{M}_4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">M</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  is more abundant in the skeletal muscle. These two enzymes have different  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Km}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Km</span></span></span></span></span></span>  values and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Km}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Km</span></span></span></span></span></span>  is indirectly proportional to affinity ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi>m</mi></msub><mo>∝</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{K}_m \propto 1/</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">∝</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span></span></span></span></span>  affinity). The skeletal muscle enzyme  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{M}_4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">M</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  has low  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi>m</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{K}_m</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  value for pyruvate and hence greater affinity for pyruvate resulting in high rate of conversion of pyruvate to lactate. The cardiac isoenzyme  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{LDH}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">LDH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  has high  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mi>m</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{K}_m</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">m</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  value for pyruvate hence lesser affinity for pyruvate, therefore low rate of conversion of pyruvate to lactate.</p>
<p>Thus the concentration of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{H}_{4}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  or  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{LDH}_{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">LDH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  isoenzyme form of lactate dehydrogenase increases in the plasma during myocardial infarction. The peak levels of LDH are maintained in the plasma for 6 days following the attack, after which it starts receding in its concentration.</p>
<p>(2) Creatine phosphokinase (CPK): This is known as the marker enzyme for the diagnosis of myocardial infarction or heart attack, because this is the first enzyme to increase within a short time in the blood plasma following a heart attack.</p>
<p>CPK is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of creatine to creatine phosphate, a high energy compound that works to supply energy during muscle contraction. Therefore this enzyme is present only in a few tissues like the cardiac muscle, skeletal muscle and the brain.</p>
<p>CPK also exists in various isoenzyme forms. It has two polypeptides 'B' &amp; 'M' that form dimers in the following combinations to give rise to three isoenzymes of CPK.</p>
<p>MB - Predominant in cardiac muscle</p>
<p>BB - Predominant in brain</p>
<p>MM - Predominant in skeletal muscle</p>
<p>Thus estimation of the isoenzyme MB is indicative of heart attack. CPK maintains a higher concentration in the plasma for 1-2 days. The concentration of CPK after the first attack is 10 times more than the normal and if another attack occurs within a day or two the concentration further increases to 100 fold and a third attack within a short span of time raises the level of CPK to 300 fold which is lethal concentration.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>(3) Transaminases: Among the two transaminases, aspartyl transaminase (AST or SGOT) increases in the plasma following an attack and the higher levels are seen in 4 to 5 days following an attack.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-02e03e96.jpeg" alt="img-117.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-75dc396f.jpeg" alt="img-118.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-93cecd7d.jpeg" alt="img-119.jpeg"></p>
<p>Vitamins are organic substances required in minute quantities in the diet to maintain the normal physiological functions of the body.</p>
<p>Vitamins are classified as (1) water soluble vitamins and (2) fat soluble vitamins.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="water-soluble-vitamins">WATER SOLUBLE VITAMINS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#water-soluble-vitamins" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The water soluble vitamins are B-complex vitamins and vitamin C. The B-complex group of vitamins includes—</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>(1) Thiamine</th><th>(2) Riboflavin</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>(3) Niacin</td><td>(4) Pyridoxine</td></tr><tr><td>(5) Pantothenic acid</td><td>(6) Biotin</td></tr><tr><td>(7) Folic acid</td><td>(8) Lipoic acid</td></tr><tr><td>(9) Cyanocobalamine</td><td>(10) Choline</td></tr><tr><td>(11) Inositol</td><td></td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="thiamine">THIAMINE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thiamine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="4e6085e6">VITAMIN—B₁<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#4e6085e6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Vitamin B₁ is also called as Anti-Beri Beri vitamin and Anti-Neuritic vitamin.</p>
<p>Chemistry: Thiamine is present as a crystal of thiamine hydrochloride. Chemically thiamine contains a pyrimidine ring and a thiazole ring linked by a methylene bridge. Both the rings are substituted.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5985d59e.jpeg" alt="img-120.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>The alcohol group on the thiazole ring is esterified with two phosphoric acid molecules to form thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). Thiamine pyrophosphate is the active co-enzyme form of thiamine.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-d1d7f733.jpeg" alt="img-121.jpeg"></p>
<p>Source: The richest sources of thiamine are rice bran, wheat bran, whole grains, nuts, germinating seeds, pulses, beans, lentils, yeast, liver, eggs, fish, meat and milk.</p>
<p>Daily requirement: This vitamin cannot be stored in the body, as it is excreted in the urine, hence it should be provided daily in the diet. However the skeletal muscle can retain this vitamin for a short duration of time. Brain cannot retain any of the thiamine.</p>
<p>The daily requirement of thiamine depends upon the calorie requirement and the carbohydrate intake. For 3000 Kcal of energy  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.5\mathrm{mg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span></span></span></span></span>  of thiamine is required per day. However</p>
<p>For normal adult males the daily requirement is from 1.5 to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2.0\mathrm{mg/day}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2.0</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg/day</span></span></span></span></span></span>
For adult females the daily requirement is from 1.0 to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.2</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.2\mathrm{mg/day}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1.2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg/day</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<p>Assay methods: Vitamin  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{B}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  is oxidized to thiochrome which can be assayed by fluorescence. Other biological and microbiological procedures are also available for its assay.</p>
<p>Metabolism: Vitamin- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{B}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  is freely absorbed by small intestine and drained into the liver. In the liver it is phosphorylated to thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP). This TPP coenzyme is present in all the tissues. There is no storage of this vitamin, hence regularly needed in the diet. About  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10\%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span>  of vitamin- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{B}_1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  taken in the diet is normally excreted in the urine.</p>
<p>Physiological functions and biochemical role: Thiamine is required for</p>
<ol>
<li>Utilization of carbohydrates in the body.</li>
<li>Maintenance of good appetite.</li>
<li>Normal brain metabolism.</li>
</ol>
<p>Thiamine in its active coenzyme form i.e. as thiamine pyrophosphate and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Mg}^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0818em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Mg</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8873em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  function as coenzyme for (1) Oxidative decarboxylation reactions and (2) Transketolation reactions. Ex.</p>
<p>For oxidative decarboxylations:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f9bdf50f.jpeg" alt="img-122.jpeg"></p>
<p>For Transketolations:</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-4655cdd7.jpeg" alt="img-123.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>Deficiency diseases: Thiamine deficiency results in impaired utilization of carbohydrates due to which pyruvate and lactate accumulates in the cells. But this impairment is not uniform; the brain cells are more affected than the skeletal muscle. Blood brain barrier becomes permeable to pyruvate in rats. Erythrocyte transketolase levels are lower then normal.</p>
<p>The symptoms of thiamine deficiency are loss of appetite (anorexia). The clinical condition of thiamine deficiency is known as 'Beri-Beri', characterized by polyneuritis (various defects of nervous system), edema, cardio-vascular changes, weakness, muscular atrophy, headache, insomnia, gastro-intestinal disorders etc. Wernicke's encephalopathy or acute thiamine deficiency is seen in alcoholics.</p>
<p>Beri-Beri is of four types viz.</p>
<p>(a) Dry Beri-Beri: In this nervous symptoms or polyneuritis predominates.
(b) Wet Beri-Beri: In this the symptoms are associated with edema and serous effusions.
(c) Acute pernicious Beri-Beri: In this the symptoms of heart are involved.
(d) Mixed Beri-Beri: All the above symptoms.</p>
<p>Another type of Beri-Beri is infantile Beri-Beri seen in breast fed children, whose mothers' milk is deficient in thiamine.</p>
<p>Antagonists: Pyrithiamine, oxythiamine and 2-n-butyl thiamine are the antagonists of thiamine. Foxes develop a type of paralysis called 'chastek paralysis' when they eat raw fish. It is caused by the presence of enzyme "thiaminase" in raw fish which destroys thiamine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="riboflavin">RIBOFLAVIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#riboflavin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chemistry: Riboflavin is made up of substituted isoalloxazine ring. To this ring ribityl alcohol is attached.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f71f0ff5.jpeg" alt="img-124.jpeg">
Riboflavin</p>
<p>The ribityl alcohol of the riboflavin is phosphorylated to form riboflavin phosphate or flavin mononucleotide (FMN).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-688027f7.jpeg" alt="img-125.jpeg">
Flavin mononucleotide (FMN)</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>Riboflavin is also linked to an adenosine nucleotide through a pyrophosphate linkage to form flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c62d6112.jpeg" alt="img-126.jpeg">
Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)</p>
<p>FMN and FAD are the two active coenzyme forms of riboflavin.</p>
<p>Source: Riboflavin is rich in animal sources like milk, liver, kidney, heart, egg yolk and in sprouts.</p>
<p>Daily requirement: The daily requirement of riboflavin depends upon the calorie requirement of an individual. For 1000 cal of energy <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">0.5\mathrm{mg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">0.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span></span></span></span></span> of riboflavin is recommended. On an average <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2.0</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.5 - 2.0\mathrm{mg/day}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2.0</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg/day</span></span></span></span></span></span> of riboflavin is recommended.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="physiological-functions-of-riboflavin">Physiological functions of riboflavin<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#physiological-functions-of-riboflavin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>It is required for the regulatory functions of some hormones concerned with carbohydrate metabolism.</li>
<li>It stimulates the optic nerve in presence of light.</li>
</ol>
<p>Coenzyme activities: FAD and FMN act as coenzyme for some enzymes called flavorproteins. They help in the oxidation-reduction reactions of cell metabolism. The hydrogens are transported by reversible reduction of the coenzyme by two hydrogen atoms added to the nitrogen (N) at positions 1 and 10. The enzyme reactions catalyzed are as follows—</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-7f6a2a20.jpeg" alt="img-127.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="deficiency-diseases">Deficiency diseases<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#deficiency-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Characteristic lesions of the lips.</li>
<li>Fissures at the angles of the mouth (cheilosis).</li>
<li>Dermatitis of the face.</li>
<li>Magenta tongue.</li>
<li>Certain functional and organic disorders of the eye.</li>
</ol>
<p>Antagonists: Dichlororiboflavin and isoriboflavin.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="niacin">NIACIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#niacin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chemistry: The chemical name of niacin is nicotinic acid. It contains a pyridine ring with a carboxylic acid.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-6478a678.jpeg" alt="img-128.jpeg">
Nicotinic acid (NIACIN)</p>
<p>Nicotinic acid is converted to its amide form called niacinamide or nicotinamide.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-d37fa4da.jpeg" alt="img-129.jpeg">
Nicotinamide (NIACINAMIDE)</p>
<p>Nicotinamide combines with a ribose phosphate and later on gets esterified to an adenine nucleotide to form the 'Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo mathvariant="normal" lspace="0em" rspace="0em">′</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{NAD}^{+})'</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NAD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose"><span class="mclose">)</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7519em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">′</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-5c883c66.jpeg" alt="img-130.jpeg">
Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD)</p>
<p>The ribose sugar of adenine may be phosphorylated to form 'Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(\mathrm{NADP}^{+})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0946em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NADP</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>  .  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NAD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NAD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NADP}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NADP</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  are the two coenzyme forms of niacin.</p>
<p>Source: Liver, fish, beans and peanuts. Niacin can also be formed in the human body form the amino acid - tryptophan.  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60\mathrm{mg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span></span></span></span></span>  of tryptophan can give rise to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1\mathrm{mg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span></span></span></span></span>  of niacin.</p>
<p>Daily requirement:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 - 20\mathrm{mg / day}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">15</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg/day</span></span></span></span></span></span> . Niacin requirements depend upon the quality and quantity of protein in the diet, as niacin can be formed from tryptophan.</p>
<p>Functions: Niacin in the form of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NAD^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NA</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">D</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NADP^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NAD</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">P</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  acts as coenzyme for a number of oxidoreductases. They act as electron acceptors during the enzymatic removal of hydrogen atoms.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NAD^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NA</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">D</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  acts as coenzyme for dehydrogenases in oxidation of various food stuffs.</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NADPH^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NADP</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  acts as coenzyme for reductases in the synthesis of fatty acids and cholesterol.</p>
<p>Functions of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NAD^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NA</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">D</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  as coenzyme</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-46cde0f0.jpeg" alt="img-131.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions-of-nadp-as-coenzyme-its-formation-and-utilization">Functions of NADP as coenzyme (its formation and utilization)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions-of-nadp-as-coenzyme-its-formation-and-utilization" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-b33c5c31.jpeg" alt="img-132.jpeg"></p>
<p>Deficiency diseases: The deficiency disease of niacin is pellagra. It is characterized by "3 Ds" i.e. Dermatitis, Diarrhoea and Dementia (headache, forgetfulness, depression, anxiety, etc.). If not treated it results in  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mtext>th</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4^{\text{th}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  'D' i.e. Death.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pyridoxine">PYRIDOXINE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pyridoxine" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="d022d2cd">VITAMIN -  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi><mn>6</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{B}_{6}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d022d2cd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chemistry: The chemical name of pyridoxine is 2-methyl-3-hydroxy-4, 5-dihydroxymethyl pyridine. The alcohol on  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mtext>th</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">4^{\text{th}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  position may be oxidized to an aldehyde to form pyridoxal or it may be substituted by an amino group to form pyridoxamine. Hence vitamin  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi><mn>6</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{B}_{6}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  exists in three forms i.e., pyridoxine, pyridoxal and pyridoxamine.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8d8a9cce.jpeg" alt="img-133.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-9c6843ff.jpeg" alt="img-134.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-d8d55ab1.jpeg" alt="img-135.jpeg"></p>
<p>The - OH group at the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>5</mn><mtext>th</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5^{\text{th}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  position may be phosphorylated to give pyridoxal phosphate and pyridoxamine phosphate. These are the two active coenzyme forms of this vitamin.</p>
<p>Source: Yeast, rice polishing, milk, meat, eggs, leafy vegetables and liver. Intestinal bacteria can also synthesize this vitamin.</p>
<p>Daily requirement:  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1.6</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2.0</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1.6 - 2.0\mathrm{mg / day}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1.6</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2.0</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg/day</span></span></span></span></span></span></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">FUNCTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Pyridoxine is essential for the growth of infants.</li>
<li>Pyridoxal phosphate acts as coenzyme for</li>
</ol>
<p>(a) Transamination reactions—takes up amino group to form pyridoxamine phosphate.
(b) Decarboxylation—in the formation of dopamine (GABA).
(c) Dehydration.
(d) Desulphuration.
(e) Deamination.
(f) Trans-sulphuration.
(g) Kynureninase enzyme in niacin synthesis.
(h) Synthesis of serotonin, catecholamines and heme.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>A Schiff's base is formed as an intermediate in the reactions catalyzed by pyridoxal phosphate.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-aed4b406.jpeg" alt="img-136.jpeg"></p>
<p>Deficiency diseases: Vitamin  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mn>6</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{B}_{6}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  deficiency is rare. However irritability, depression, peripheral neuropathy, hypochromic microcytic anemia, cystathionuria, etc. may be seen.</p>
<p>Antagonists: Isonicotinic acid hydrazide (INH) and hydrazoline. Infants when treated with INH for tuberculosis suffer from convulsions because of structural resemblance of INH with vitamin  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="bold">B</mi><mn>6</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{B}_6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8361em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">B</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pantothenic-acid">PANTOTHENIC ACID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pantothenic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chemistry: Pantothenic acid contains  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -alanine and pantoic acid joined by a peptide bond.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-f96cde52.jpeg" alt="img-137.jpeg">
Pantothenic acid</p>
<p>The active coenzyme form of pantothenic acid is coenzyme-A. Coenzyme-A is formed by combination of pantothenic acid with adenine, ribose, phosphoric acid (Adenine nucleotide) and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -mercaptoethylamine.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-89a7eb9a.jpeg" alt="img-138.jpeg"></p>
<p>Source: Pantothenic in Greek means 'from everywhere'. It is so named because it is present in all the common food sources. Its richest source is honey. The intestinal flora also supplies considerable amount of this vitamin.</p>
<p>Food source: Cereals, nuts, oil seeds, egg, liver, wheat grain, legumes, rice polishing, milk, meat and fish are good sources of this vitamin. Vegetables like potato have relatively less amount of this vitamin.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">FUNCTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Pantothenic acid is required for the growth of infants and children.</li>
<li>Coenzyme-A is required for the activation of acetate to acetyl-CoA.</li>
<li>Co-A is required to form succinyl-CoA for the citric acid cycle to operate normally.</li>
<li>Coenzyme-A is required for the activation of fatty acids for their oxidation.</li>
<li>Coenzyme-A is also required for fatty acid and cholesterol synthesis.</li>
</ol>
<p>Deficiency diseases: As this vitamin is widely distributed, the deficiency rarely occurs. However nausea, vomiting, G.I tract disorders, irritability, inadequate growth, anemia, fatty liver, etc. may occur due to its deficiency. Impaired growth and reproduction, loss of hair, sensitivity to insulin, burning feet syndrome are other deficiency manifestations of this vitamin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="biotin">BIOTIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biotin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chemistry: It is a heterocyclic compound containing sulphur and a valeric acid side chain. It is attached to lysine residue of the enzyme through the valeric acid to form the active coenzyme i.e., biocytin.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c31b6b46.jpeg" alt="img-139.jpeg"></p>
<p>Source: Egg, liver, fish, meat, beans, germinating seeds, intestinal flora, and peanut. Richest source is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  honey. Poor source is  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span>  fruits and vegetables.</p>
<p>Daily requirement: Only if the intestinal flora is disturbed, the requirement of biotin ranges form  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>300</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">y</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100 - 300\mu \mathrm{g} / \mathrm{day}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">day</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="functions">FUNCTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#functions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Biotin is involved in  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  transfer and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  fixation. Ex.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-c201ae3f.jpeg" alt="img-140.jpeg"></p>
<p>Deficiency diseases: Only if raw egg white which contains avidin is taken, it binds and inhibits the absorption of biotin that leads to deficiency. Signs include—alopecia, greying of hair and nervous symptoms.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="folic-acid">FOLIC ACID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#folic-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Chemistry: There are three components in folic acid viz. (1) Pteridine (2) Para aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and (3) Glutamic acid.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>Pteridine nucleus comprises of pyrimidine and pyrazine rings. Further pteridine and PABA are collectively called pteroic acid. All the components are together known as pteroyl glutamic acid (PGA) i.e. folic acid.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-ef6b095b.jpeg" alt="img-141.jpeg">
Folic acid</p>
<p>Folic acid is readily absorbed by the intestine and not stored but undergoes reduction in the liver by the enzyme folic acid reductase that reduces folic acid to tetrahydrofolic acid (THF). This is the active coenzyme form of folic acid. This reaction requires  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NADPH^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NADP</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">H</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and ascorbic acid.</p>
<p>Folic acid  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><munderover><mo stretchy="true" minsize="3.0em">→</mo><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi></mrow></mrow></mpadded><mpadded width="+0.6em" lspace="0.3em"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">U</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></mrow></mpadded></munderover></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\xrightarrow[\mathrm{NADPH} + \mathrm{Ascorbic~acid}]{\mathrm{FOLIC~ACID~REDUCTASE}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.7668em; vertical-align: -0.6664em;"></span><span class="mrel x-arrow"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 1.1003em;"><span style="top: -3.322em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight x-arrow-pad"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">FOLIC</span><span class="mspace nobreak mtight"><span class="mtight">&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">ACID</span><span class="mspace nobreak mtight"><span class="mtight">&nbsp;</span></span><span class="mord mathrm mtight">REDUCTASE</span></span></span></span></span><span class="svg-align" style="top: -2.689em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="hide-tail" style="height: 0.522em; min-width: 1.469em;"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="400em" height="0.522em" viewBox="0 0 400000 522" preserveAspectRatio="xMaxYMin slice"><path d="M0 241v40h399891c-47.3 35.3-84 78-110 128
-16.7 32-27.7 63.7-33 95 0 1.3-.2 2.7-.5 4-.3 1.3-.5 2.3-.5 3 0 7.3 6.7 11 20
 11 8 0 13.2-.8 15.5-2.5 2.3-1.7 4.2-5.5 5.5-11.5 2-13.3 5.7-27 11-41 14.7-44.7
