Histidine</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(a) Histidinemia</td><td>Histidase</td></tr><tr><td>8. Proline</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>(a) Hyperprolinemia type-I</td><td>Proline oxidase</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Human beings are prototrophic for nucleic acids as these are synthesized in the body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="digestion-and-absorption">DIGESTION AND ABSORPTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#digestion-and-absorption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nucleic acids are consumed in large quantities owing to their presence in all cells. These nucleic acids are not utilized by the body; instead they are digested, catabolized and excreted. They are taken in the form of nucleoproteins, which are conjugated proteins with amino acids constituting the protein part and nucleic acids constituting the prosthetic part.</p>
<p>The protein part of nucleoprotein is acted upon by proteolytic enzymes of gastric and intestinal juices. Nucleic acids are acted upon by nucleases (ribonuclease and deoxyribonuclease) of pancreatic and intestinal juices to produce mononucleotides. Nucleotides are hydrolyzed to nucleosides by nucleotidases (intestinal phosphatase) Nucleosides are absorbed by intestinal mucosa to portal blood and transported to the liver and supplied through systemic circulation to other viscera. The enzyme nucleosidases liberate the free purine and pyrimidine base and ribose or deoxyribose from the nucleosides.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="catabolism-of-nucleosides">CATABOLISM OF NUCLEOSIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#catabolism-of-nucleosides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>Purine nucleoside — formation of uric acid: End product of purine metabolism is uric acid (in primates including man and dog). In lower animals, birds and reptiles, uric acid is converted to</li>
</ol>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>allantoin by the action of enzyme uricase. Liver, spleen, kidney, intestinal mucosa contain enzymes capable of acting on the purine ring in the free or combined state.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-a9cdaade.jpeg" alt="img-226.jpeg"></p>
<p>Uric acid metabolism: Uric acid exists as sodium ureate in plasma. Maximum amount of sodium ureate that can dissolve in the blood plasma is about  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>7</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>100</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7\mathrm{mg} / 100\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span><span class="mord">/100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span> . At this point there will be saturation of blood with sodium ureate. Above this it gets precipitated. Uric acid concentration does not vary with greater intake of uric acid in the diet because on intake of higher concentration in the diet the synthesis of uric acid in the body will be inhibited. Hence there is a balanced amount of uric acid in the body.</p>
<p>Miscible pool of uric acid: Total amount of uric acid present in the body in the dissolved state in males is 3.4 to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>7.0</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7.0\mathrm{mg / dl}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">7.0</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mg/dl</span></span></span></span></span></span>  and in females it is 2.4 to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5.7</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5.7\mathrm{mg / dl}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">5.7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mg/dl</span></span></span></span></span></span> .</p>
<p>Modes of excretion: It is excreted in urine by glomerular filtration. Amount excreted is 250 to 750 mgs/day. It is also excreted through bile, to about  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><msup><mn>5</mn><mtext>th</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1/5^{\text{th}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0991em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">5</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  of the total amount into the intestine. In the intestine it will be converted to  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NH}_{3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NH</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  either by action of intestinal flora or autoxidation of the uric acid. Estimation of blood uric acid in ureotelic animals has importance in the diagnosis of gout and Von-Gierke's disease.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="conditions-varying-the-blood-levels-of-uric-acid">Conditions varying the blood levels of uric acid<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#conditions-varying-the-blood-levels-of-uric-acid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Gout: If the concentration of uric acid exceeds  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>7</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>100</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7\mathrm{mg} / 100\mathrm{ml}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span><span class="mord">/100</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">ml</span></span></span></span></span></span>  in the blood plasma, the uric acid gets precipitated as sodium ureate crystals that cannot be excreted hence gets deposited in the soft tissues. There is abnormal deposition in joints and tendons. This abnormal deposition of sodium ureate crystals</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>in soft tissue is known as TOPHI. Because of this the tissue gets degraded or degenerated at the bone joints leading to degeneration of neighbouring tissues as well. Degeneration causes inflammation of the joint.</p>
<p>Gouty arthritis: Generally the metacarpal phalangeal joints and metatarsal phalangeal joints are affected by this gout. Knee joint is also affected. There are two types of gout—</p>
<ol>
<li>Primary Gout: Enzyme 'PRPP synthetase' shows altered kinetics leading to overproduction of PRPP and hence overproduction of purines.</li>
<li>Secondary gout: This is due to—</li>
</ol>
<p>(i) Excess catabolism of purine as in polycythemia.
(ii) Decreased excretion of uric acid as in renal failure.</p>
<p>Gout can be controlled by—</p>
<ol>
<li>Uricosuric drugs like salicylates, cinchopher, adrenal cortical hormones, which cause increased excretion of uric acid in urine by decreasing its re-absorption.</li>
<li>Allopurinol (Allantoin) a structural analogue to hypoxanthine which competitively inhibits xanthine oxidase and decreases the production of uric acid.</li>
</ol>
<p>Von-Gierke's disease: In this disease there is an overproduction of uric acid. The HMP shunt pathway is overactive due to the deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase thereby producing excessive amounts of ribose-5-phosphate. This leads to the overproduction of PRPP, hence the uric acid.</p>
<p>Methods of estimation: Phosphotungstic acid method, Fehling's method and Autoanalyzer.</p>
<p>Conditions varying the blood level of uric acids: Whenever there is cell death, the nucleic acids are released and converted to purines and finally uric acid is formed. The conditions where uric acid level increases in the blood are—(a) excessive tissue destruction and (b) gout.</p>
<p>Excessive tissue destruction: Is seen in—</p>
<ol>
<li>Old age</li>
<li>Febrile diseases</li>
<li>Hypoxia</li>
<li>Trauma</li>
<li>Kidney dysfunction or total renal failure</li>
<li>High non-vegetarian diets</li>
<li>Pyrimidine nucleoside: Pyrimidine nucleosides are catabolized in the liver. The products of breakdown of pyrimidine ring are ammonia and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  which are converted into urea for excretion.</li>
</ol>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-0faed7b4.jpeg" alt="img-227.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="biosynthesis-of-purine-nucleotides">BIOSYNTHESIS OF PURINE NUCLEOTIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biosynthesis-of-purine-nucleotides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>There are two pathways by which nucleotides are made available for the formation of nucleic acids (1) Denovo synthesis i.e. new synthesis and (2) Salvage process i.e. recycling of the bases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="de-novo-synthesis">DE NOVO SYNTHESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#de-novo-synthesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>De novo (all over again) synthesis of purine nucleotides is synthesis of purines anew. The purine ring is synthesized along with the nucleotide i.e. attached to the ribose sugar provided from HMP pathway. This pathway supplies ribose sugar for the formation of the nucleotide. Activated form of D-ribose-5-phosphate serves as the starting material on which purine ring is build up step by step. Precursors of the members of purine ring are—</p>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  N-1 is contributed by nitrogen of aspartate.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  N-3 and N-9 arise from amide nitrogen of glutamine.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  C-2 and C-8 originate from the formate.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  C-6 is embedded from respiratory carbon dioxide.
<span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">✓</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\checkmark</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6922em;"></span><span class="mord amsrm">✓</span></span></span></span></span>  C-4, C-5 and N-7 are taken up from glycine.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-defbf5a4.jpeg" alt="img-228.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-55598d18.jpeg" alt="img-229.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-15b6f57d.jpeg" alt="img-230.jpeg"></p>
<p>Regulation of purine nucleotide biosynthesis: Purine biosynthesis is regulated by feedback inhibition. This inhibition is in the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>1</mn><mtext>st</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1^{\text{st}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7936em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7936em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">st</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  step. It is the committed step which is generally irreversible. Once the committed step is passed over, the product has to be formed. The different mechanisms by which it is regulated are—</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-9701b3fe.jpeg" alt="img-231.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="salvage-pathway">SALVAGE PATHWAY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#salvage-pathway" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The de-novo synthesis does not occur in all the cells. Brain cells and leukocytes lack this mechanism. In these cells purine synthesis occurs by salvage pathway. Salvage pathway involves synthesis of purine nucleotides from free purine bases, which are salvaged from dietary sources and tissue breakdown. This pathway is promoted by the action of two enzymes which convert free purines into purine nucleotides for reuse. The enzymes are (1) Adenine phosphoribosyl transferase and (2) Hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT).</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-b8f5dd4d.jpeg" alt="img-232.jpeg"></p>
<p><strong>Lesch-Nyhan syndrome:</strong> This is a genetic disorder caused due to the deficiency of the enzyme ‘Hypoxanthine Guanine Phospho Ribosyl Transferase (HGPRT)’. When this enzyme is deficient, guanine, xanthine and hypoxanthine are not salvaged and hence degraded to uric acid. This is especially seen in male children. In female children the gene is recessive and is a carrier. It is a male dominant gene. Such males show (1) mental retardation and (2) tendency for self destruction.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="biosynthesis-of-pyrimidine-nucleotides">BIOSYNTHESIS OF PYRIMIDINE NUCLEOTIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biosynthesis-of-pyrimidine-nucleotides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Pyrimidine nucleotide biosynthesis takes place in a different manner from that of purine nucleotides. The six membered pyrimidine ring is made first and then attached to ribose phosphate. The synthesis begins with carbon dioxide and ammonia combining to form carbamoyl phosphate catalysed by the cytosolic enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-II. Carbamoyl phosphate combines with aspartate to form carbamoyl aspartate aided by the enzyme aspartate transcarbamoylase. Dihydroorotate is formed from carbamoyl aspartate by removal of water and closure of the ring under the influence of the enzyme dihydroorotase. Dihydroorotase is oxidized to orotic acid by dehydrogenase which uses <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{NAD^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">NA</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">D</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> as the electron acceptor. Orotic acid is attached to ribose to yield orotidylic acid. Orotidylate is then decaroxylated to form uridylate. Uridylate is then converted to all the other pyrimidine nucleotides viz., CMP, UMP &amp; TMP. The reaction steps involved in the biosynthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides are given under.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-a23446d2.jpeg" alt="img-233.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p>Regulation of pyrimidine biosynthesis: Regulation of pyrimidine biosynthesis is by feed back inhibition at the committed step i.e. the reaction catalyzed by the enzyme aspartate transcarbamoylase. This is negatively inhibited by the end product i.e. CTP. The second site is at carbamoyl phosphate synthase-II which is feed back inhibited by UMP.</p>
<p>Orotic aciduria: It is a metabolic disorder of pyrimidine biosynthesis characterized by accumulation of orotic acid in blood and its increased excretion in urine. It is caused due to the deficiency of enzyme orotidylic acid phosphorylase and orotidylic acid decarboxylase or orotic phosphoribosyl transferase. This leads to non-conversion of orotic acid to UMP. This may even affect the synthesis of other nucleotides. It is generally found in children who show retarded mental development and growth as there is no proper synthesis of DNA. They show megaloblastic anemia. This can be overcome by injection of CTP and UTP.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="biosynthesis-of-deoxyribonucleotides">BIOSYNTHESIS OF DEOXYRIBONUCLEOTIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biosynthesis-of-deoxyribonucleotides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Deoxyribonucleotides are obtained from ribonucleotides. Thioredoxin is a protein which takes part in the conversion of ribonucleotides to deoxyribonucleotides.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="purine-deoxynucleotides">Purine Deoxynucleotides:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#purine-deoxynucleotides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-fb53a85e.jpeg" alt="img-234.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-8ff06be6.jpeg" alt="img-235.jpeg"></p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-510de44a.jpeg" alt="img-236.jpeg"></p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pyrimidine-deoxynucleotides">Pyrimidine Deoxynucleotides:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pyrimidine-deoxynucleotides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="15">15<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#15" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-56c88be8.jpeg" alt="img-237.jpeg"></p>
<p>Hormones are organic substances required in minute quantities produced by ductless glands directly into the blood and act on some other tissue (target tissue).</p>
<p>Endocrine glands and the hormones produced</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Endocrine gland</th><th>Hormones produced</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>1. Pituitary gland</td><td></td></tr><tr><td>a) Anterior pituitary (Adenohypophysis)</td><td>1. Growth Hormone (GH)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Thyrotropic or Thyroid Stimulating Hormone (TSH)</li>
<li>Adrenocorticotropic Hormone (ACTH)</li>
<li>Pancreotropic Hormone</li>
<li>Metabolic Hormone</li>
<li>Interstitial Cell Stimulating Hormone (ICSH) or Leutinising Hormone (LH)</li>
<li>Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH)</li>
<li>Prolactin or Luteotropic Hormone (LTH)</li>
<li>Melanocyte Stimulating Hormone (MSH)  |
|  b) Posterior pituitary (Neurohypophysis) | 1. Oxytocin</li>
<li>Vasopressin or Antidiuretic Hormone (ADH)  |
|  2. Thyroid gland | 1. Thyroxine (T4)</li>
<li>Triiodothyronine (T3)</li>
<li>Calcitonin  |
|  3. Parathyroid gland | 1. Parathormone  |
|  4. Pancreas |   |
|  a) β-cells of islets of langerhans
b) α-cells of islets of langerhans | 1. Insulin</li>
<li>Glucagon  |</li>
</ol>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>5. Gastro-intestinal mucosa</th><th></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>a) Stomach</td><td>1. Gastrin.</td></tr><tr><td>b) Intestine</td><td>1. Secretin.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol start="2">
<li>Enterokinin.</li>
<li>Pancreozymin.</li>
<li>Cholecystokinin.</li>
<li>Enterogastrone.</li>
<li>Somatostatin.  |
|  6. Adrenal gland |   |
|  a) Adrenal cortex | 1. Glucocorticoids—(i) Cortisol,
(ii) Corticosterone</li>
<li>Mineralocorticoids—(i) Aldosterone</li>
<li>Androgens  |
|  b) Adrenal medulla | 1. Epinephrine (Adrenaline)</li>
<li>Norepinephrine (Nor-Adrenaline)  |
|  7. Gonads |   |
|  a) Testis | 1. Testosterone  |
|  b) Ovaries | 1. Estrogen</li>
<li>Progesterone  |</li>
</ol>
<p>In addition to these major glands, there are other few minor endocrine glands like the pineal gland, the thymus gland, placenta, kidney, corpus leutum etc.</p>
<p>The hypothalamic part of the central nervous system on receiving suitable information from the environment or other parts of the body produces the hormones known as the 'release factors' which pass through the hypophyseal-hypothalamic portal vein to the master endocrine gland - the pituitary gland. This master gland produces the respective tropic hormone in response to the release factor. The tropic hormone will then stimulate another endocrine gland which will produce the specific hormone required for the action as per the information received by the CNS. This specific hormone or target hormone will finally act on the target tissue or the target cell.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-cf45f416.jpeg" alt="img-238.jpeg"></p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Example No. 1</th><th>General Scheme of hormone action</th><th>Example No. 2</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>Shock ↓</td><td>External stimuli ↓</td><td>Cold ↓</td></tr><tr><td>Hypothalamus ↓</td><td>Hypothalamus ↓</td><td>Hypothalamus ↓</td></tr><tr><td>ACTH-Release hormone ↓</td><td>Release factor ↓</td><td>Thyrotropic release factor ↓</td></tr><tr><td>Pituitary gland ↓</td><td>Pituitary gland ↓</td><td>Pituitary gland ↓</td></tr><tr><td>ACTH ↓</td><td>Tropic hormone ↓</td><td>Thyrotropic hormone (TSH) ↓</td></tr><tr><td>Adrenal gland ↓</td><td>Respective endocrine gland ↓</td><td>Thyroid gland ↓</td></tr><tr><td>Epinephrine ↓</td><td>Specific hormone ↓</td><td>Thyroxine ↓</td></tr><tr><td>Muscles ↓</td><td>Target tissues ↓</td><td>Various tissues ↓</td></tr><tr><td>Glycogenolysis</td><td>Metabolic action</td><td>Increased BMR</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Classification of hormones: The hormones are divided into four classes—</p>
<ol>
<li>Peptide hormones: All the hormones of the hypothalamus, pituitary, G.I. mucosa, and pancreas.</li>
<li>Steroid hormones: The hormones of adrenal cortex and gonads.</li>
<li>Catecholamines: Epinephrine and norepinephrine.</li>
<li>Thyroid hormones: Thyroxine and triiodothyronine.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="mechanism-of-hormone-action">Mechanism of hormone action:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#mechanism-of-hormone-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Enhancement of enzyme synthesis: The steroid hormones and the thyroid hormones enter the cell and combine with the specific receptor protein to form 'receptor protein-hormone complex'. This complex will then bind to a specific site on DNA and initiate or enhance the synthesis of mRNA which in turn synthesizes the protein i.e. enzymes. Therefore the cell reactions speed up.</li>
<li>Change in cell permeability: Hormones like insulin binds to a specific receptor on the cell membrane which results in alteration of the permeability of the cell to certain substances like glucose, amino acids and ions. The entry of these substances will bring a change in cell reactions.</li>
<li>Action through a second messenger (cAMP): Hormones like epinephrine, glucagon bind to a regulatory site on the cell membrane. On the inner side of this regulatory site, an enzyme known as adenyl cyclase is present that converts ATP to cAMP which then activates certain protein kinases that in turn will phosphorylate certain enzymes. Some enzymes on phosphorylation become active whereas some other enzymes become inactive. Certain reactions are therefore stimulated while others are inhibited.</li>
</ol>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-54ad8787.jpeg" alt="img-239.jpeg"></p>
<p>Feedback regulation of hormone production: The production of hormones is regulated by feedback mechanism. There are two types of feedback regulation (1) Negative feedback regulation and (2) Positive feedback regulation.</p>
<ol>
<li>Negative feedback regulation: When the target hormone is in little excess, then this excess hormone will inhibit the production of its tropic hormone. The tropic hormone in turn will stop the release of the release factors. The inhibitory action of the tropic hormone over the release factor is known as the short loop feedback. At other instances the target hormone can itself inhibit the release factor this is known as long loop feed back.</li>
</ol>
<ol start="2">
<li>Positive feedback regulation: Estrogen stimulates the production of luteinizing hormone.</li>
</ol>
<p>Secretion of hormones from endocrine glands: The peptide hormones and the catecholamines are secreted by a process called exocytosis. Steroid hormones are secreted by passive diffusion.</p>
<p>Circulation of hormones in blood: The water soluble peptide hormones and the catecholamines circulate in free form in the blood. Steroid and thyroid hormones circulate bound to specific proteins known as binding, carrier or transport proteins ex Thyroxine binding globulin (TBG).</p>
<p>Degradation and excretion of hormones: All the hormones are degraded and excreted. Peptide hormones are degraded in the liver and/or kidney. The catecholamines, steroids and the thyroid hormones are inactivated directly by enzymatic modification in the blood and/or in the liver.</p>
<p>Disorders of the endocrines: There are three major classes of endocrine disorders</p>
<ol>
<li>Insufficient hormone production: This may be due to abnormal function or destruction of the endocrine gland.</li>
<li>Excess hormone production: This is due to tumors of the gland.</li>
<li>Altered tissue responsiveness to hormone effects: (a) Immunity to hormones (b) Defective or absence of receptor (c) Inactive receptor hormone complex. These are the causes that lead to ineffectiveness of hormones though they are produced in normal amounts.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypothalamus">HYPOTHALAMUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypothalamus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>All the hormones of the hypothalamus are peptide hormones and they are known as release factors or releasing hormones. Their function is to stimulate the production of anterior pituitary hormones. Each of the anterior pituitary hormones has its own release factor ex. ACTH has ACTH-release hormone.</p>
<p>The neurons of the hypothalamus produce two hormones (1) Oxytocin (2) Vasopressin or Anti-diuretic Hormone (ADH).</p>
<p>The neurons extend to the posterior lobe of the pituitary where these two hormones are stored in the nerve endings. Neurophysin help in the transport of these hormones from hypothalamus to the posterior pituitary (Neurophysin I and II are proteins).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anterior-pituitary">ANTERIOR PITUITARY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anterior-pituitary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is the master gland and controls the activities and development of other endocrine glands. The hormones produced by the anterior pituitary are known as tropic hormones. These are the hormones that stimulate the respective glands ex Thyrotropic hormone stimulates the thyroid gland for the production of thyroid hormones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="tropic-hormones-and-their-site-of-action">Tropic hormones and their site of action<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tropic-hormones-and-their-site-of-action" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<p>Endocrine gland Hormone produced Site of action 1. Pituitary Growth Hormone and prolactin do not act as tropic hormones; instead they act as the target hormones.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="growth-hormone-gh">GROWTH HORMONE (GH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#growth-hormone-gh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>It is a protein made up of 191 amino acids having a molecular weight of 22,000 Da. It has two disulphide bridges.</p>
<p>Stimuli: Sleep, stress, exercise, low blood glucose, high amino acid content in blood and starvation.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h3 level="3" id="actions">Actions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h3></div>
<ol>
<li>
<p>It stimulates protein synthesis by enhancing amino acid uptake by the cells (this results in a positive nitrogen balance).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It helps in the retention of phosphorous, potassium, sodium and calcium.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It enhances lipolysis by accelerating the mobilization of fat from adipose tissue resulting in increased oxidation of fats in liver and muscle.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It inhibits glucose uptake by the extrahepatic tissue (hyperglycemic effect).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It increases liver glycogen by enhancing glycogenesis (via gluconeogenesis).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>It stimulates the production of somatostatin (which aids in sulphur addition to cartilage, therefore GH is also known as somatotropin). This somatostatin inturn inhibits the release of GH.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>(7) It increases synthesis of DNA and RNA in the tissues.</p>
<p>(8) It enhances erythropoiesis.</p>
<p>(9) It stimulates the growth of somatic tissue by enhancing the growth of cartilage; chondrogenesis and oesteogenesis.</p>
<p>Disorders: Excess production of GH in childhood results in gigantism, wherein the person shows a giant like appearance with abnormally long hands and legs.</p>
<p>Excessive production of GH after the usual age of full skeletal growth results in acromegaly and is due to a tumor of the adenohypophysis. The characters of acromegaly are broadened skull, hands and fingers. The soft tissue of the nose, lips, forehead and scalp are thickened.</p>
<p>Hyposecretion of GH results in dwarfism. It is characterized by short height, but fully developed mental and sexual ability.</p>
<p>PROLACTIN LACTOGENIC HORMONE AND MAMMOTROPIN</p>
<p>It is a protein hormone with 199 amino acids having a MW of 23,000 Da. There are three intrachain disulphide bridges.</p>
<p>Stimuli: Pregnancy, nursing or breast stimulation, sleep and stress.</p>
<p>Actions:</p>
<p>Effects on breast: Development of the mammary tissue, production of milk (lactogenic) and ejaculation of milk.Amenorrhaeic effect: It has an amenorrhaeic effect (absence of menses) on the reproductive system. Therefore breast feeding serves as a contraceptive method.Effect on corpus luteum: It activates the corpus luteum and stimulates production of progesterone by the developed corpus luteum.Excess: The excessive production of prolactin results in amenorrhea, galactorrhea (unnecessary discharge of milk) and enlargement of breast.</p>
<p>POSTERIOR PITUTARY OXYTOCIN</p>
<p>(Greek: Rapid birth)</p>
<p>Chemistry: It is a nona-peptide (9 amino acids) with a disulphide (--S--S--) bridge between 1^{st} and 6^{th} cysteine amino acids. Union of these two cysteine molecules thus give rise to one cystine molecule hence it also considered as octa-peptide (8 amino acids).</p>
<p>Stimuli:</p>
<p>The neural impulses from the stimulation of nipples (termed as milk let down response).Vaginal and uterine contractions (leading to rapid birth).Estrogen stimulates oxytocin production whereas progesterone inhibits its production.</p>
<p>Actions:</p>
<p>Causes contraction of uterine smooth muscle at the time of child birth.Stimulates the ejaculation of milk by producing constriction of specialized myo-epithelial cells.Helps in the movement of spermatozoa in the female reproductive tract.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vasopressin-or-antidiuretic-hormone-adh">VASOPRESSIN OR ANTIDIURETIC HORMONE (ADH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vasopressin-or-antidiuretic-hormone-adh" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is a nona-peptide (9 amino acids) with a disulphide (-S-S-) bridge between 1st and 6th cysteine amino acids. These two cysteine molecules unite thus giving rise to one cystine molecule hence it also considered as octa-peptide (8 amino acids).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="stimuli">Stimuli:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stimuli" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>The osmotic pressure of the plasma, also known as oncotic pressure is the primary stimuli for the release of ADH. If the plasma is hypertonic then there is increased secretion of ADH. If the plasma is hypotonic the secretion of ADH is suppressed.</li>
<li>Low blood volume</li>
<li>Hypotension (low blood pressure)</li>
<li>Emotional stress</li>
<li>Drugs like nicotine</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="actions">Actions:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#actions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>It increases the rate of water re-absorption from the latter part of the distal convoluted renal tubules and collecting ducts (antidiuretic effect). This mechanism is adapted to control dehydration and to compensate the excess salt intake.</li>
<li>It causes constriction of smooth muscle, leading to the constriction of arteries and capillaries (vascular system). Due to the action of ADH as a vasoconstrictor it results in an increase in the blood pressure.</li>
<li>It is an inhibitor of gonadotropins especially LH.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Under production of ADH leads to diabetes insipidus. This is characterized by increased excretion of dilute urine. Normal excretion of urine is 1500 ml/day. In diabetes insipidus it rises up to 6 to 20 l/day. The condition is known as polyuria. This results in thirst leading to increased water intake.</p>
<p>The low secretion of ADH may be due to lesions of hypophysis or hypothalamus or due to non responsiveness of nephrons in the kidney, known as hereditary nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Alcohol inhibits the release of ADH thereby causing diabetes insipidus. Overproduction results in water retention and hyponatremia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thyroid-gland">THYROID GLAND<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thyroid-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is a pair of glands situated on either side of the trachea. The development and secretion of the thyroid gland is controlled by TSH.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thyroid-hormones">THYROID HORMONES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thyroid-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The hormones secreted by thyroid are (1) Thyroxine (T₄) &amp; (2) Triiodothyronine (T₃).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="synthesis-of-thyroid-hormones">Synthesis of thyroid hormones:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#synthesis-of-thyroid-hormones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>The thyroid hormones are synthesized from tyrosine in presence of iodine. Plasma contains iodine ion (I⁻), which is taken up by the thyroid gland by an active transport mechanism, against the concentration gradient through Na⁺, K⁺-ATPase pump, which requires energy. In the gland, iodide is converted to active iodine (I or I⁺) by the action of an enzyme thyroperoxidase which requires hydrogen peroxide.</p>
<p>In the thyroid gland there is a glycoprotein called thyroglobulin, Mw-660,000 Da, containing 5000 amino acids among which 140 are tyrosine residues. The tyrosine residues of this protein are iodinated to form T₃ and T₄. The steps of their synthesis on the protein are—</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-b984af67.jpeg" alt="img-240.jpeg"></p>
<p>Out of the 140 tyrosine residues of the thyroglobulin some will be in the form of tetraiodothyronine, some will be in the form of triiodothyronine and some in the form of diiodotyrosine and monoiodotyrosine.</p>
<p>On stimulation with TSH the thyroglobulin is hydrolysed by proteolytic enzymes in the lysosomes and the free amino acids are released. Only  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  is the active species. The thyroid hormones are inactivated upon oxidation to triiodothyroacetic acid and finally deiodinated.</p>
<p>Functions of thyroid hormones: The target organ or tissues of thyroid hormones are almost all the tissues.</p>
<ol>
<li>They stimulate  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Na^{+}K^{+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">N</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">a</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> -ATPase thereby increasing the rate of oxygen consumption and heat production—BMR (except gonads, spleen and adult brain).</li>
<li>They increase the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats and proteins.</li>
<li>It causes increased absorption of glucose from intestine. It increases glycogenolysis in liver and muscle. It promotes gluconeogenesis. (Hyperglycemic effect).</li>
<li>It increases RNA synthesis, amino acid transport and protein synthesis.</li>
<li>In hypothermic conditions it uncouples oxidative phosphorylation by swelling mitochondria thereby producing heat.</li>
<li>They enhance the growth and development of many tissues; due to enhancement of protein synthesis by thyroid hormones.</li>
<li>It aids in the conversion of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -carotene to vitamin A.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pathophysiology">Pathophysiology:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pathophysiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Hypothyroidism: It is a condition wherein there are insufficient amounts of  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mn>3</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  &amp;  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mn>4</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{4}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">4</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> . This may be due to (a) disease of thyroid gland (failure) or (b) disease of pituitary/hypothalamus or (c) deficiency of iodine.</li>
</ol>
<p>In children: Hypothyroidism results in cretinism, characterized by dwarfism, thick tongue and skin mental retardation and sexual undevelopment.</p>
<p>In adults: Hypothyroidism results in myxoedema, which is characterized by thick, dry and waxy skin, dull mental ability and high sensitivity to cold.</p>
<p>In all the cases of hypothyroidism BMR is low (--20 to --40%) and hypercholesterolinemia is seen. T_{3} and T_{4} administration is the only remedy.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Hyperthyroidism or thyrotoxicosis: It is due to excessive production of thyroid hormones. Main cause is tumor of the gland.</li>
</ol>
<p>Grave's disease: This is due to long acting thyroid stimulator (LATS) and LATS protector, which act similar to that of TSH resulting in over production of thyroid hormones due to which BMR increases (+20 to +80%), there will be loss of weight, increased heart rate, inability to sleep etc.</p>
<p>Treatment: Antithyroid drugs control Grave's disease.</p>
<p>Ex. (1) Thiocyanate, perchlorate and ouabain--inhibit iodine uptake by the gland.</p>
<p>(2) Thiourea and thiouracil--inhibit thyroperoxidase.</p>
<p>Goiter: Enlargement of thyroid gland is called goiter. It is due to (1) deficiency of iodine (2) tumors of thyroid (3) excess of TSH and (4) LATS.</p>
<p>Exophthalmic goiter: It is the bulging of the eyeballs out of the face, which is also due to hyperthyroidism.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parathyroid-gland">PARATHYROID GLAND<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parathyroid-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A pair of glands present just behind the thyroids.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="parathormone">PARATHORMONE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#parathormone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>They produce the hormone called parathormone or parathyroid hormone (PTH). It is a polypeptide of 84 amino acids with molecular weight of 9500 Da. It is synthesized as a preprohormone which is converted to prohormone by removal of 25 amino acids from the N-terminal end. Finally parathormone is formed by the removal of 6 more amino acids. It is secreted when blood calcium is low. Its secretion is inhibited when calcium is high in the blood. The target organs for parathormone are bone and kidney.</p>
<p>Functions:</p>
<ol>
<li>Raises serum calcium by—</li>
</ol>
<p>(a) Formation of calcitriol in the kidney, which helps in the absorption of Ca^{2+} from the intestine.</p>
<p>(b) Mobilization of Ca^{2+} from the bones.</p>
<p>(c) Reducing the excretion of calcium by the kidney.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Decreases serum phosphate by increasing its excretion by the kidney.</li>
</ol>
<p>Calcitonin: It is a hormone produced by the thyroid gland having 32 amino acids. It prevents the movement of Ca^{2+} from bone; it causes phosphate deposition in the bone and prevents phosphate excretion by the kidney. Therefore it is known as the parathormone antagonist.</p>
<p>Hypoparathyroidism: It occurs due to the accidental removal of parathyroid during neck or thyroid surgery. It can also occur due to auto-immune destruction of the gland. The resulting condition is known as tetany—due to which there is neuro-muscular irritability and hypocalcemia.</p>
<p>Hyperparathyroidism: Occurs mainly due to tumors of the gland. It results in high serum calcium, low serum phosphate, bone destruction and kidney stones.</p>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pancreas">PANCREAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The islets of langerhans of the pancreas function as the endocrine cells. The alpha cells produce glucagon, beta cells produce insulin, D &amp; F cells produce somatostatin and pancreatic polypeptides respectively.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="insulin">INSULIN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#insulin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is a polypeptide with a molecular weight of 5734 Da. It is made up of two chains, chain 'A' having 21 amino acids and chain 'B' having 30 amino acids.</p>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251219-65a71f16.jpeg" alt="img-241.jpeg"></p>
<p>There are two interchain disulphide bonds (1) between A7 &amp; B7 and (2) between A20 &amp; B19. There is one intrachain disulphide bond in A chain between  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>6</mn><mtext>th</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6^{\text{th}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">6</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  and  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>11</mn><mtext>th</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">11^{\text{th}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">1</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">th</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>  amino acids.</p>
<p>Insulin is synthesized as a preproinsulin which is converted to proinsulin by the removal of 23 amino acids from the N-terminal end. Proinsulin is the inactive storage form of insulin which contains an additional 'C' chain containing 35 amino acids. Active insulin is formed due to cleavage of 'C' chain from proinsulin by proteolytic enzymes.</p>
<p>Stimulation for insulin secretion: High blood glucose, amino acids, fatty acids, ketone bodies and hormones like glucagon, GH, cortisol etc. Epinephrine inhibits insulin secretion by decreasing cAMP.</p>
<p>Target cells: The target cells for insulin action are mainly muscle, liver and adipose tissue. Other cells like lymphocytes, fibroblasts and mammary glands are also acted upon by insulin. It can be said that almost all the cells of the body are dependent upon insulin for uptake of glucose except brain, RBC, G.I tract, liver, retina of eye and pancreas itself.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="actions-or-effects-of-insulin">Actions or effects of insulin:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#actions-or-effects-of-insulin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>Helps in the transport of glucose, amino acids,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mi mathvariant="bold">K</mi><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathbf{K}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathbf">K</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ,  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Ca^{2+}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8141em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">C</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">a</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> , P and nucleotides through the cell membrane.</li>
<li>It enhances the utilization of glucose by the cell by activating the enzymes of energy production (glycolysis) and of energy storage (glycogenesis and lipogenesis).</li>
<li>It inhibits the enzymes of glucose production in the cells (gluconeogenesis).</li>
</ol>
<p>All the above three mechanisms affect in lowering the blood glucose level (i.e. hypoglycemic effect).</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>It inhibits lipolysis.</li>
<li>It stimulates HMP shunt pathway resulting in production of NADPH for lipid synthesis.</li>
<li>It enhances protein synthesis.</li>
</ol>
<p>AMANULLAH</p>
<p>MEDICAL BIOCHEMISTRY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="inactivation-and-degradation-of-insulin">Inactivation and degradation of insulin:<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inactivation-and-degradation-of-insulin" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>The hormone-receptor complex is taken up by the lysosomes of the target cells and proteolysis occurs.</li>
<li>In liver glutathione-insulin transhydrogenase reduces the disulphide linkages with reduced glutathione and thereby separating the A and B chains. The A and B chains are then cleaved by insulinase enzyme.</li>
</ol>
<p>Diabetes mellitus: Details given under the chapter 'Carbohydrate Metabolism'.</p>
<p>Hyperinsulinism: Excessive production of insulin, mainly due to the tumors of the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> -cells which results in hypoglycemia associated with sweating, tremors, fainting attacks. This can be relieved by injecting glucose or by oral supply of sugar.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="glucagon">GLUCAGON<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#glucagon" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>It is a peptide of 29 amino acids having a molecular weight of 3485 Da. It is known as Hyperglycemic-Glycogenolytic Factor (HGF). It is secreted by the  <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> -cells of the islets of langerhans in the pancreas. Hypoglycemia stimulates its production. It acts by activating hepatic adenyl cyclase thereby promoting glycogenolysis. It inhibits protein synthesis, fatty acids and cholesterol synthesis. It promotes gluconeogenesis, lipolysis and ketone body formation. Overall, it has hyperglycemic effect. Hyperglucagonism antagonizes the insulin action thereby causing hyperglycemia i.e. diabetes mellitus. Hypoglucagonism results in hypoglycemic convulsions and shock exhibiting sweating, shivering or fainting. It is inactivated in the liver by glucagonase.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adrenals">ADRENALS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenals" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Adrenal glands are a pair of glands situated on the dorsal side of the kidney. Each gland is a composite of two structures (1) Adrenal medulla and (2) Adrenal cortex.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="adrenal-medulla">ADRENAL MEDULLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-medulla" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>They arise from the autonomic nervous system. The cells of the adrenals are called pheochromocytes or chromaffin cells (due to dichromate staining).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="catecholamines">CATECHOLAMINES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#catecholamines" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>The hormones produced by the adrenal medulla are known as catecholamines. They are—(1) Epinephrine (adrenaline) (2) Norepinephrine (nor-adrenaline).</p>
